talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —This is a decision that the minister has made.
—He does not need to justify it?

—The justification is that the matters have been referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions in 17 cases. I think it should be apparent that this is the proper course of action to take, that these matters should be pursued in the courts of law, and that is the action that has been taken.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. I refer the minister to her answer to my question yesterday regarding refugees from East Timor, where she stated:

question.para: The government expects the East Timorese who are able to do so to return before their visas expire.

Minister, the UNHCR may be willing to say it is safe for refugees to return in the sense that they no longer have a well-founded fear of persecution in that they are not likely to get shot. But is it not the case that water and food supplies, water quality, shelter and access to medical and education services are currently clearly inadequate? How can the government guarantee that it is safe to return to these conditions? Why is the government trying to ensure East Timorese are returned to these conditions as soon as next week?

talk.start.para: —I thank the senator for his question, and I can indicate to him that I have some more information—not a lot but nonetheless some more—in relation to his question on this matter yesterday. I have had a look at the brief that I have been provided by the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. It does not address that specific point, and I will speak to the minister and see whether there is anything he has to say in relation to that matter.

answer.para: Before concluding, can I say that I noticed the perhaps unintentionally glib way that you referred to the UNHCR as though they may make a decision and it is not one that we ought take notice of. I, and I think plenty of other senators and members, have significant respect for that body, and I would not so easily dismiss out of hand a decision they have apparently made if I had a different view. Nonetheless, I will put your view to the minister for immigration and ask him whether there is anything further he wishes to add.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. In relation to the UNHCR, Minister, isn't the role of that body simply to determine whether or not people have a well-founded fear of persecution? It is not that body's role to determine the conditions in which people return in terms of health, education, water and food supplies. The minister also stated yesterday that return is voluntary. Is the government aware of statements from a number of East Timorese refugees in Australia requesting an extension of their visas until conditions improve? How can returning these people be described as voluntary? What will the government do with any East Timorese who are unwilling to leave by next week? I would remind the minister, in seeking that information from her counterpart, that she did give a commitment yesterday to get back to me as quickly as she could on that day with any remaining answers. I have not had any extra material to date, so I would ask her to see if she could get more detail from Minister Ruddock on that issue as quickly as possible.

—Part of the answer that I will table after question time deals with the question of people who do not want to return at this point. The minister's advice in relation to that matter is that, if those people have a good reason to extend their stay here beyond 8 December, they can approach him on an individual basis.

—My question is to Senator Herron representing the Minister for Aged Care. Will the minister confirm press reports that the government will be abandoning the policy of coalescence in aged care, a policy that was rejected by the Productivity Commission? Will he also confirm that the Prime Minister's office has been forced to intervene to resolve the issue, given the failure of the Minister for Aged Care to work with the sector towards a solution? Isn't the government's backflip on this issue a response to pressure from the Queensland coalition backbenchers, led by the member for Fadden, and does the minister support the attacks by the member for Fadden against Minister Bishop on this issue? Isn't this yet another example of the failure of the Minister for Aged Care to handle difficult issues in her portfolio?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —One thing I have learned after being in this place about nine years is to gauge media reports and such things very carefully. An even more important thing I have learned is to gauge even more carefully assertions made by the Labor Party spokesman. I know Senator Hogg has not been here that long but he has been very active in Labor Party affairs, and I am sure that he would be very wary of propositions that were put to him. I do not believe those assertions that are in the paper. I have certainly campaigned for a resolution to the coalescence question—as all of my fellow Queensland senators have done—because it is a significant thing for Queensland. I am sure that is why Senator Hogg is putting this proposal as well. But I think it should be put in the context that the government publicly released the Productivity Commission's report on nursing home subsidies on 31 March this year. The report endorses the government's intention to move towards uniform national subsidies for residential aged care. The Productivity Commission also found no evidence of a funding crisis in the residential aged care industry. The Productivity Commission says:

answer.para: The substantial prices paid for bed licences do not sit comfortably with the view that there is a funding crisis in the sector. Similarly, the commission notes that many homes, private for profit and not for profit alike, are producing operating surpluses under the current subsidy levels, even in the lower subsidy states.

Now that the Productivity Commission's report has been released, the government has conducted a series of consultations, and those consultations are continuing. Industry and consumer stakeholders in all states have been consulted on the key issues raised, and when these consultations are completed there will be a whole of government decision on the recommendations and the way ahead. Just because the industry want a decision accelerated in their favour in my own state—and I can understand that because that is what industry does, and I commend them for their activity—that is not going to force the hand of the government into making a decision that will influence the whole of the country.

The government will be especially mindful of the impact on the industry and on those older Australians who live in nursing homes and hostels. In 1995-96 the Labor government spent $2.5 billion on residential aged care across Australia. The outlay in 1999-2000 is budgeted to be $3.5 billion. That is an increase of 42 per cent since the coalition was elected to government in 1996. We will be continuing to consult with the industry and with the residents of nursing homes and hostels. We will respond to our reports at the appropriate time, because it is an important question that needs to be determined by government, that needs a whole of government response to be developed.

talk.start.para: —I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister aware that Aged Care Queensland has been left out of the discussions between the sector and the government on this policy backdown? Can he confirm that, along with the ill-fated accommodation bonds, this is another of the government's aged care reforms that will be jettisoned by the government?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —At the risk of repeating myself, which I am not wont to do, Aged Care Queensland has been very active in lobbying all my colleagues and me. To my understanding, they have briefed departmental offices. If the implication was that they have not met with the minister, then I will follow up on that. But I am certainly aware of the fact that there have been extensive consultations from Aged Care Queensland both with the minister's officers and with the department.

—This question without notice is to the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator Vanstone. Will the minister inform the Senate of the impact of the government's Tough on Drugs strategy on stemming the flow of the domestic production of amphetamines?

—I thank Senator Payne for the question. She has a longstanding interest in the problems of drug abuse in Australia. Domestic amphetamine production is the major supplier of amphetamines on the Australian market. All too often we get slightly distracted by focusing on the drugs coming across the border and therefore do not focus enough on the job that is being done in Australia to produce these drugs. The modus operandi is fairly simple. Over-the-counter pharmaceutical tablets are purchased—or, more often than not, stolen—by criminals to extract the pseudoephedrine from which methylamphetamine can be produced. It is a pretty simple process. A packet of 90 over-the-counter pharmaceutical tablets can be purchased without prescription for roughly $20. By reacting this pseudoephedrine with other chemicals—more difficult to acquire but not so difficult that they cannot be purchased on the black market—for a value of about $50, pure methylamphetamine can be produced. So, for a $70 investment, with the wrong connections in the underworld, a return in the vicinity of $5,000 can be realised.

answer.para: The number of clandestine laboratories is increasing. There were 4,418 arrests nationwide for amphetamine offences in 1997-98, compared with 3,585 in 1996-97—up 23 per cent in one year. So it is important to focus on this growing problem of amphetamine production in Australia, and it is important to realise just how profitable and lucrative this sort of business is. Cocaine can be cut on heroin, heroin can be cut down to 50 per cent; this sort of stuff can be cut down to have only three per cent pure amphetamine in what is sold on the market. So the profit margin is obviously significantly higher.

The Bureau of Criminal Intelligence organised the National Chemical Diversion Conference in Canberra yesterday and today. That highlights the importance of the greatest weapon against criminals of law enforcement internationally and nationally, and that is cooperation. I have had occasion to say in here a number of times that we have been successful in major drug seizures because of international cooperation, and our cooperation has provided success overseas because we have been cooperating in reverse.

Similarly, when you come to the question of amphetamine production it is important to focus on cooperation. This conference brings together the law enforcement investigators who are working at the coalface, the chemical technicians, the transportation industry and health officials—all of whom have an interest in this growing and very serious problem in Australia. The exchange of information between law enforcement agencies is vital. The control of precursor chemicals is, of course, difficult because of the large-scale industrial use. These chemicals are extremely dangerous. For every kilo of methylamphetamine produced, there are 10 kilos of toxic waste. So, Senator Brown, when you have not got something to do, you could help us in law enforcement in relation to amphetamines. You should have a very strong interest in this matter because—

talk.start.para: —Senator Vanstone, you should direct your remarks to the chair, not across the chamber.

—Through you, Madam President—for every one kilo of methylamphetamine produced, 10 kilos of very dangerous toxic waste are turned out. It can contaminate the air, the ground, water and buildings. These drugs are also particularly dangerous. When law enforcement goes in to dismantle these labs, explosions frequently occur. We have had police officers very significantly injured for the rest of their lives because of these drugs. (Time expired)

—My question is to Senator Herron, representing the Minister for Aged Care. Is the minister aware that a report from a director of a nursing training institute in Sydney identifies numerous instances in which untrained staff in hostels are administering dangerous drugs to residents? Is the minister also aware that, as the report notes, overdoses and underdoses are becoming commonplace in hostels as unqualified staff hand out complicated medications and drugs, including morphine? Is the minister aware that there have been numerous admissions to hospital as a direct result? Just what is the government doing to protect older Australians in hostels from dangerous medication administering practices by unqualified staff?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator West for that question and her continued interest in nursing, given her background. I am not aware of that particular report in the media today but it is true that there is an ongoing problem in relation to medications overall, to answer the last part of the question first, and the misuse of medication both in nursing homes and hospitals, but more seriously in nursing homes and hostels because of the age of the patients concerned, the difficulty in remembering the dosages and the fact that there is a difficulty in the staffing of hostels and nursing homes insofar as qualifications and the understanding of the people who dispense these materials.

answer.para: Both the previous government and the current government have adopted standards that require accreditation in these places to overcome these particular issues, but they will vary from time to time. Again, as Senator West asserts, it is well known, for example, that hospital admissions to a large degree are as a result of inadequate or excessive medication, and problems arise from that in the wider community as well as in nursing homes. To summarise that, in answer to Senator West's question: that is governed under the accreditation criteria, both by the states and the federal government, so that those issues can be addressed.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Don't reports of unqualified staff administering dangerous drugs to older Australians raise serious concerns about the medical safety of many of the aged care institutions in this country? Shouldn't we be doing everything to ensure that the safety of frail older Australians is not put at risk? I also ask the minister: what are the implications arising out of this in relation to the dispensing to patients of schedule 8 drugs by untrained staff? There are some breaches of the laws there, and it is really of grave concern to everybody. What is this government going to do about those?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —In answer to the first supplementary question, yes, that is correct. In answer to the second, the government is doing something about it by ensuring that the criteria established, both at the state and the federal level, with the cooperation of the states, are instituted and enforced so that the activity should not occur.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Service Tax: Exemptions for Ex-Service Personnel

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, ex-service personnel who serve their country in theatres of war and who, as a result of their injuries and health, are recipients of the TPI pension are granted a sales tax exemption on new motor vehicles and parts. Does the government intend to provide an equivalent GST exemption?

—The GST exemptions flow through, Senator, so there is no particular change there. I think that probably deals with the question that you have asked. The government has a great concern and interest to make sure that ex-servicemen are looked after appropriately. That has always been this government's policy and, over the period of time that we have been in government, we have taken every possible step to make sure that the benefits available to ex-servicemen are maintained and, where possible, improved.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister has clarified that GST exemptions flow on. Can the minister assure the Senate that these recipients will not be worse off under the new tax system in relation to vehicles, and under what process?

—Let me make a general comment in relation to vehicles overall. Under our policy, as a result of the removal of the wholesale sales tax, the overall price of vehicles falls. So, this government, unlike the Labor Party, believes in cheaper vehicles, not more expensive vehicles. Also, of course, you would be aware that pensions are being increased in real terms. This is our policy; it is not Labor Party policy. We believe the package of reforms that we have brought down will be to the benefit of not only ex-servicemen and TPI recipients but the Australian community. This is what this tax reform is about: improving the conditions of the Australian community and improving, of course, the benefits available to those on welfare.

—My question is addressed to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Can the minister explain why the Howard government has refused to fund the AMA's planned education campaign designed to promote an end to the antiquated system of extremely long hours being worked by young doctors in public hospitals?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Denman for her question and her concern about the extremely long hours worked by doctors.
—Young doctors.

—Young doctors. I remember the day when I was a young doctor. I did a survey as then president of the Resident Medical Officers Association and found that we were working 100 hours a week, for which we were paid a pittance. I am sure that that could be replicated among many other professions.

answer.para: The short answer to the question is that it is up to the doctors themselves to take particular action, as we did in those days; it is not for government to do it. Does Senator Denman really expect the taxpayer to subsidise young doctors because they are working hard? That is the way you get experience in this game: you go out and you work hard; you get hands-on experience looking after sick people so that you can get some value out of it. The government is not going to subsidise young doctors.

I am delighted to have the Labor Party advocating that the taxpayers subsidise young doctors. It might be the foretaste of the Labor Party's policy on health care in this country, because we have been waiting three years for the policy. Is this the first bit of policy—that the Labor Party will subsidise young doctors to stop them working such long hours? I welcome the question. The facts of the matter are that we do not believe it is government's responsibility to do this. But I am happy to ask the minister if he has anything further to add to the answer that I have just given.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the minister concede that excessive workloads are a major contributing factor in the high rate of adverse events and preventable deaths and injuries in our hospitals? Why does the Howard government continue to tolerate this dangerous practice?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —In an industrial situation, they are the sorts of arguments that I would expect the resident medical officers to use. In fact, that is the argument which I used to use, so I have no difficulty in answering that particular question. Of course, any single event in our hospitals that is deleterious to a patient should be condemned. There is no question about that. There are procedures in hospitals to prevent this occurrence. It is the Labor Party that has control of the majority of hospitals in the country. I think that is the sort of question that should be addressed to Premier Bob Carr, Premier Steve Bracks or the other Labor premiers around the country.
—Name them!

—Mr Beattie. The states have responsibility for the hours that are worked within their hospital system and for adverse events that are occurring. It shows that there is a complete misunderstanding of the hospital and medicare system. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources. Is the minister aware that the radioactive waste reprocessing contract between ANSTO and Cogema, which was announced a fortnight ago by DFAT, is contrary to the accord between the French Greens and their coalition partners, which specifically states that `recycling at The Hague will be reviewed and no new recycling contract will be undertaken'? Is the minister aware that the ship which is now on its way to northern France carrying 308 spent fuel rods from the Lucas Heights facility may not be allowed to deposit its toxic cargo at its destination? In light of this latest revelation about the supposedly secure contract with France, is it the case that Australia will have no reprocessing options for the waste from a new, and unnecessary, nuclear reactor?

—I take the opportunity of this question to congratulate ANSTO on the very successful, efficient shipment that occurred late last week. I think they did an outstanding job in very smoothly transporting those spent fuel rods from Lucas Heights onto the ships and out of Australia, in accordance with our policy that we should reprocess those spent fuel rods and return the waste from those spent fuel rods in time for storage in a facility in Australia.

answer.para: As to the Democrats' assertion that, because the French Greens have some difficulty with this matter, we will not be able to have our spent fuel rods reprocessed at Cogema, I point out to Senator Stott Despoja that ANSTO does have a binding contract with Cogema for this reprocessing. In August of this year Australia exchanged diplomatic notes with the French government in respect of this matter. The note specifically states:

The Government of the French Republic assures the government of Australia that it does not intend to take or support any legislative or regulatory initiative or any other action which would prevent or hinder execution of the contract relating to the delivery of the spent fuel to Cogema and its transport to the processing site in France.
Whatever the views of the French Greens may be, the French government has made it abun dantly clear that the contract with Cogema will be honoured.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister aware of the accord between the French Greens and their socialist coalition partners? Does the minister recall his own statements and the statements of his department and agencies that the new nuclear reactor would not be constructed in Australia until the issue of waste disposal was resolved—the minister's own words? Would the minister please explain whether it remains the policy of his department to co-locate the future storage of the reprocessed high level waste with the proposed national radioactive waste repository?

question.para: Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Government senators should be aware that the supplementary question has been asked and the minister should be called to answer.

interjection.para: Senator Ian Macdonald interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Ian Macdonald, cease interjecting.

—I think there are several questions there which I am given one minute to attempt to answer. It is not the government's policy to co-locate. We have only ever said that it remains a possibility that we will co-locate the facility for the storage of long-lived intermediate level waste with the low-lived and short-lived intermediate level waste repository. We do have a strategy for the waste from the Lucas Heights reactor. That is why we are proceeding with the new reactor. That waste will be the result of the reprocessing of the spent fuel rods. According to the contract that we have with Cogema, that waste will be returned to Australia in 2015 and it will be stored in a long-lived intermediate level storage facility, which may or may not be co-located with the repository.

—My question is to Senator Newman, the Minister for Family and Community Services. Is the minister aware that studies in New Zealand have found that charities have had to absorb a five to eight per cent increase in overall running costs as a result of administering the GST? What action will the government take to ensure the expected five to eight per cent increase in running costs for charities here in Australia does not lead to less resources to help the needy? Is a $200 GST gift voucher the limit of the Howard government's assistance?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —That was a pretty silly question. But, having said that, no, that is not the extent of the assistance to charities, and the senator should be well aware of the fact that that is not the case. For example, a great deal of assistance is being given to the community sector by virtue of funding peak bodies to provide assistance to the smaller community sector organisations. Only just over a week ago I announced the establishment of a 13 number for the community sector, the education sector and the small business sector to ring to get information on specific points. In addition, the government has made it quite clear that it will be monitoring the impact of tax reform on the charitable sector. There is no intention by the government to make life more difficult for the charitable sector in the provision of services which are funded very largely by government.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Those changes do not help them with long-term running costs. Is the minister aware of a report in the Financial Review of 22 November which states that the government's GST high-roller tax rebate `should not be construed as pandering to the wealthy'? Why then have high rollers been exempted from paying a GST while, at the same time, the government is forcing charities to pay a GST on government grants they receive, as confirmed by Minister Anthony when he said:

question.para: I make the point that it is likely that any grant made by the government to charities will be subject to a GST.

Why does the Howard government, with the support of some Democrats, want to tax charities and the poor yet it is more than happy to hand out multimillion dollar GST breaks to Liberal cronies and their high-roller mates?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Madam President, that is just the normal political rhetoric that we are accustomed to from them. The charitable sector does not pay a GST on payments received for specific services to people with disabilities.

answer.para: Senator Sherry interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Sherry, you have asked a question. You should not continue to shout while the minister is answering it, and nor should other senators.

—Madam President, if Senator Sherry wants to learn what is not the case, I would refer him to a press release by the shadow minister, Mr Swan, which is absolutely crammed full of inaccuracies. They do not pay a GST—he would not listen to me before—on specified services to people with disabilities, to the aged, to child care or on non-commercial services. They do not pay a GST on donations, on the sale of red noses or second-hand goods or on raffles or bingo. They do not even have to register if their total turnover is less than $100,000.
—Madam President, I raise a point of order.
—You are asking for information and I am giving it to you.

—Madam President, the point of order is relevance. The question went to the confirmation by Minister Anthony in respect of a question from Mr Swan that grants to charities will be subject to a GST. Why won't she admit it?
—There is no point of order.

—You have already had that answer given several times, so I am not going to waste time. I am trying to give you more information that you obviously do not know either. If these charities are not registered, there is no ability to claim back the GST. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston. The government is committed to increasing IT&T skills and providing new opportunities for employment in the growing industry of telecommunications. Will the minister inform the Senate of the positive impact call centres are having on jobs growth, particularly in regional Australia? Is the minister aware of any alternative policy approaches? What would be the impact should those be implemented?

question.para: Senator Lundy interjecting—

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —We will come to you in moment, Senator Lundy. Senator Calvert's question is a very important one because it highlights the extraordinary significance of not only the telecommunications sector but also the role that call centres have to play. Global telemarketing is about a $275 billion industry. In Australia, call centres are worth about $2½ billion and are growing at the rate of about 20 per cent a year. Indeed, salaries are going up by about 3.9 per cent. Most of the people employed—in other words, more than 50 per cent—are earning more than $30,000. If you are in the sales marketing area you can earn a lot more than that. Indeed, customer service operators are earning up to $52,000 and telephone salespeople are earning up to $72,000.

answer.para: Madam President, you would have thought this was very good news, wouldn't you. But no, what is the attitude of the trade union movement? A spokesperson from the Bendigo Trades Hall Council says, `Call centre jobs are not worth having.' That is the starting point. When she was asked about a proposal to create 200 new jobs in Hamilton, a very depressed rural area which used to be the wool capital of the world but has been going south for a number of years—Senator Troeth and I know it very well—she said, `I'd tell them to forget it. It's hardly worth it. Call centres are the new sweatshop factory labour.' If there is one thing I would have thought we have all learnt in recent times it is that rural and regional Australia has particular problems, but especially with unemployment. The levels of both adult and youth unemployment have been consistently higher than in metropolitan areas. Is that a given, or isn't it? Do we disagree on that proposition? We don't, do we?
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You would not have thought we did. But then we look at what Mr Martin Ferguson had to say only a month or so ago. He surprised a group of young farmers in Canberra by suggesting that the problems in the bush—bank closures, the loss of schools and hospitals—were the same as those in the cities. In other words, the bush does not have any special problems. This is a long-running record. Gough used to say that the bush had never had it so good; Keating used to trot it out on a regular basis; and here we have the latest spokesman in the area saying the same sort of thing. And now we have the unions opposing call centres, which are one of the great growth opportunities for jobs in rural and regional Australia. We must bear in mind that Mr Ferguson said this after the Victorian election. I would have thought that, if there was a lesson that even he might have learnt, it was that there are some special factors at work in rural Australia.

answer.para: I think this is absolutely deplorable. Of course, the unions are now embarking on this huge membership drive. They know that call centres are disastrous because about only 10 per cent of people there are actually union members. So they have to get out there and ramp it up. What do they say? When you talk to the Queensland branch secretary of the CEPU he says, `The problem is that a lot of employees don't even want to know that conditions aren't so good'—in other words, we are going to spend a lot of money telling them what the problems are so they have to join the union movement. You would have thought that Labor, with all its poll driven attitudes—Mr Beazley is out there looking at polls on the GST and polls on the referendum—would have learnt something, that it would have discovered that in the real world the unions are not the end of the line.

talk.start.para: —You are so predictable. Get some new lines.

—When Mr McMullan achieved a bit of internal democracy and persuaded the local branch of the ALP to diminish the weighting in favour of the union movement, Senator Lundy said that the downside of full rank and file was marginalising and reducing the trade union movement. There it is—a wholly owned subsidiary, a spokesperson for the CPSU. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to Senator Herron, representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Is the minister aware of the crisis meeting held this weekend by the AMA and the medical defence organisations to discuss the pressures which are forcing up the price of medical indemnity insurance? What steps has the government taken to reduce the burden of medical indemnity insurance on doctors and, in particular, to reduce the number of practitioners who are abandoning obstetrics and gynaecology because of extremely high premiums?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I saw this question passed to Senator Faulkner. He looked at it and said to himself, `This one really stinks.' So he handed it on to Senator Mackay. When Senator Mackay smelled it she said, `This is a crock of X. I think I will hand it on to Senator Crowley.' Senator Crowley said—
—Order! There is too much noise in the chamber and, Senator Herron, I draw your attention to the question.

—Thank you, Madam President. Senator Crowley asked the question because she was the only one that thought it was fertiliser, was strong and would produce policy. So she has asked the question. This is a serious problem. The costs of medical defence insurance have gone through the roof in this country. It is part of a worldwide phenomenon. There are some areas where the increasing incidence of litigation parallels the number of lawyers in the country. It is a particular problem in relation to obstetrics and gynaecology. I recall one of my colleagues saying that it is now a blame and claim society in that everybody expects a perfect result and, if they do not get it, they consider that it is time for litigation.

answer.para: This problem is one that has to be addressed by the public as a whole—by the whole of society. It is inevitable that unless some action is taken by society as a whole this problem will escalate in the community. It is something that the community will have to address if they expect the very high standards of health care that they get in this country. The standards of health care in this country are as good as any in the world, if not better in many respects, particularly in relation to obstetrics and gynaecology. This serious question needs to be addressed because it will produce problems in the delivery of services throughout the country.

Senator Crowley referred particularly to obstetrics and gynaecology. It has reached the stage in some American states where obstetricians and gynaecologists who love their profession are getting rid of all their assets. I have actually seen a sign saying something like, `I have no assets. If you wish to sue me as a result of any incident, that is your prerogative. The reality is that I have no assets.' That has occurred in the US. I think it was in Miami that obstetricians refused to do any obstetrics at all to put the state on notice and to bring this to a head.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I am not at all sure what to make of that generalised comment about this terribly important issue.

question.para: Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senators on my right will come to order.

—Minister, particularly in the light of the insurance premiums increasing dramatically for obstetrics and gynaecology practitioners, and in light of the fact that those premiums are very different from one state to another, would you please answer how the minister will ensure that obstetrics and gynaecology services will remain available in rural areas if the present trend of doctors to cease providing these services because of the rapidly rising cost of medical indemnity insurance continues?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The first point to make is in relation to premiums, which are set by insurers. The Commonwealth government has no control over those premiums, which are based on business considerations. Issues relating to litigation and medical practice, as I mentioned previously, are a matter for state governments. The government is obviously concerned about the cost of private indemnity insurance as it relates to Medicare rebates and is addressing this issue through the relative values study. The relative values study is currently determining the cost of running a medical practice. It should be noted that in November of last year the Commonwealth introduced a substantially increased rebate for obstetricians performing complex births. The fee now payable is $964 and is expected to inject funding of almost $7 million per year into private obstetric practices. In addition to that, the states have taken action. My own state of Queensland introduced under the previous coalition government a flying obstetrician service for remote areas. (Time expired)
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Senator Hutchins asked me a question without notice on 29 November in relation to aged care waiting lists. I have received a reply from the minister and seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

Senator HUTCHINS —My question is directed to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Aged Care. Can the minister confirm that the coalition came to power with a major performance target in aged care to reduce waiting times? Is the minister aware that the annual report of the Department of Health and Aged Care shows a 36 per cent increase in the waiting times for residential aged care over the last two years, now rising to an average of 68 days?

Senator HUTCHINS —If I can assist the minister: on page 226 of the department's report, it quotes clearly that there was an increase in the waiting period from 1997-98 of 50 days to 1998-99 of 68 days. Isn't it a fact that this 36 per cent increase in waiting time for residential aged care over the last two years is undeniable evidence of the failure of this government's aged care reforms? Further, despite all the attempts to explain away this increase, isn't it a fact that older Australians now must somehow struggle to remain in the community longer while they desperately search for, on average, over two months for a nursing bed home?
SENATOR HERRON —The Minister for Aged Care has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
ENTRY PERIODS FOR NURSING HOME CARE
Response:
The Government is committed to ensuring that older people can access residential care when they need it.

Figures from the Department of Health and Aged Care confirm that when an older person needs care urgently, a place can generally be found for them straight away. In fact, 18% of nursing home residents are placed within two days of Aged Care Assessment Team (ACAT) approval (1998-99) In emergencies, residents can be placed before the ACAT assessment has occurred.

For 1998/99, the period between assessment by an ACAT and a person's entry to permanent residential care was 68 days, on average. This is for all residential aged care services, including hostels. Admission to nursing homes is less, at 57 days, and admission to hostels is more, at 85 days. In most cases, older people and their families need time to visit different facilities, make a decision, and arrange their affairs before they move

Differences in the way aged care entry times are calculated have produced higher figures in 1998/99 than for previous years. This does not mean that residents are actually waiting longer. Comparisons over time are not valid for a number of reasons.

Firstly, as part of the Aged Care Reforms in 1997 an ACAT approval for nursing home admission is valid for one year, to bring it in line with the hostel approval period, rather than the 90 days which used to apply.

This takes pressure off people entering nursing homes and gives them more time to make decisions. This gives older people time to visit different facilities, consider their options, settle their affairs and make arrangements with the facility of their choice before they enter care. Some older people may obtain ACAT assessment but choose not to proceed with entry to residential care for quite some time, while others may prefer to wait for a place in a particular facility, for instance due to religious preferences. It is therefore misleading to refer to this as a `waiting period'

Secondly, the change in nursing home ACAT approval to one year also means that ACATs do not have to postpone an approval until they are sure the resident could find a place, as was sometimes the case in the past.

Thirdly, the success of ageing-in-place also affects entry periods because in the past if a person moved from a hostel to a nursing home this would have been counted as a new admission, with a very short waiting time. Up to 40% of hostel discharges in the past were to nursing homes, which would have reduced the average waiting time substantially.

Since the Aged Care Reforms fewer people have had to move from a hostel to a nursing home as they can receive higher levels of care in the low care service. This has a statistical effect on how entry periods are calculated.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, pursuant to standing order 74(5), I ask the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government for an explanation as to why answers have not been provided to the following questions on notice: No. 1600, which I asked on 28 September 1999; No. 1701, which I asked on 22 October 1999; No. 1702, which I asked on 22 October 1999; No. 1703, which I asked on the same day; and No. 1704, which I asked on the same day?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Mackay for the courtesy of advising me that she was going to raise these issues. They are questions which were asked of me in my representative capacity and were directed to Mr Anderson. Concerning question No. 1600 in relation to the certified air-ground radio service at Yulara in the Northern Territory, I am advised that the answer has been slightly delayed because information being provided by Airservices Australia to the department has just been provided. I am told that the senator's question will be answered as soon as possible, although I add that the trial has been completed. I referred to that earlier this week in question time.

speech.para: Concerning questions Nos 1701 and 1702, I apologise for the fact that they are a couple of days late. They were asked only on 22 October. The reason for the delay is that on 22 October my department was gearing up for the Regional Australia Summit, which was a major exercise for the whole of the depart ment. Even though a limited number of officers were directly involved, the whole of the department was particularly busy at the time as it was putting together the process for the launch of the first of our rural transaction centres which was opened at the end of October. So the department has been extremely busy. The answers are now a couple of days outside the 30-day period. I am told by my department that the answers to questions Nos 1701 and 1702 are expected to be lodged tomorrow or the next day with the Table Office.

In relation to questions Nos 1703 and 1704, both of which deal with the Regional Australia Summit—as do questions Nos 1701 and 1702—I can inform Senator Mackay and the Senate that the answers to those last two questions have been provided to the Table Office today and I have sent Senator Mackay copies of those answers.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by ministers to questions without notice asked by opposition senators today.

The Howard government has now proven that it is even more secretive than most Australians would have assumed. We have had some desperate attempts by government ministers in recent times to hide and cover up their actions as ministers. A classic example is Senator Hill and Senator Alston invoking cabinet-in-confidence as a reason for hiding details of the Federation Fund, when cabinet had absolutely nothing to do with carriage of the part of the program that was in question. That was outrageous.

Then we had Senator Newman capping that effort, hiding the so-called seminal document on welfare reform that she was prevented by the Prime Minister from launching at the National Press Club in September. The Prime Minister's office gagged Senator Newman, and she then used two new and flimsy grounds of public interest immunity to gag bureaucrats and failed to come clean on the document. What were those public interest immunity grounds? They were, firstly, that non-cabinet documents might prejudice cabinet considerations and, secondly, that tabling the document might confuse the public debate.

Those excuses were met with amazement and derision right around this building: amazement that a minister would invent two new grounds of public interest immunity and derision at her claim that transparency could lead to public confusion rather than public information. It was best described as a `mushroom ground' for public interest immunity: `Don't let the poor old public into the secret about anything that the government is up to. After all, if you do they might get confused.' Now there is a document in the public arena from the Clerk of the Senate stating that those two grounds were, in his words:
. . . not among the established grounds for public interest immunity claims . . .
and that he had not heard of them before. Basically, Senator Newman was making up those public interest immunity grounds on the run.

Now we have three new excuses from Minister Wooldridge to hide details about the MRI scandal. He is arguing that public interest immunity is legitimate because disclosure of MRI details prejudices the government's relationship with the profession, disclosure could be misleading as to the reasons for the decisions taken, and the information includes information about the affairs of radiologists and the college. This is even more absurd. No-one knows what the first two grounds mean. Even the Clerk of the Senate could not understand what was being said. They are just inventions. It is gobbledegook from the government again. The third ground could relate to breach of privacy or commercial-in-confidence, but that is not stated. If Minister Wooldridge felt secure in using a privacy ground, one assumes he would say so. You can only conclude that that particular ground—the third ground used by Minister Wooldridge, the affairs of radiologists—is also nonsense.

We know how secretive this government is. We know how it likes to cover up these details, to hide them from the parliament and to hide them from the public. Now we learn how secretive the government is, and not only about its own affairs. It is aiding and abetting big American multinationals' access to every detail about Australian citizens including, probably, the improper use of electoral roll details. As far as I can see, this is just another example of two-faced behaviour from this government. This is the principle of the government: whatever you do, hide the reasons for your ministerial decisions; cover up. That is part and parcel of the modus operandi of the Howard government. It stands exposed again in the way it does business. Now we learn about PBL and US multinational Acxiom. There are a lot of questions to answer here and this government has got to front up. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The diatribe by Senator Faulkner is somewhat stupid, if I could put it that way. This government, above all other governments in the history of Federation, is as open and transparent as a polished pane of glass. There are no secrets at all. What did Senator Faulkner substantiate his statements with? Nothing. It is a hypothesis; a whispering campaign.

speech.para: This government is open and transparent—so much so that the privacy legislation that is to apply to collection, storage, use and disclosure of personal information is an initiative of this government.

talk.start.para: —Where is it?
—It is proposed legislation and it will be introduced. Senator Lundy said:

speech.para: . . . given that the Howard government has consistently dropped the ball on privacy legislation covering the commercial sector, what is there to prevent other companies from accessing—
the database that she spoke about—
which the developers hope will contain the personal details of 15 million Australians?

The database is not accessible—if it exists, with 15 million Australians in it. This is the scare campaign that the Labor Party runs with. The Labor Party is a party in decline. For the past decade or so, the Labor Party has had to rely on the aggregation of small interest groups throughout Australia, sometimes the arty people and the small trade union groups that exist now—only 25 per cent of our work force. The aggregation of these could just get you over the line. To run a scare campaign on the government I find quite reprehensible. We all know that the secrecy surrounding the Hawke and Keating governments was an art form. It was established by those governments as an art form. You could not penetrate them.

One of the criticisms of this government that Senator Faulkner made was of the Federation Fund. In denigrating it, you take away the wonderful benefits that those people in rural and remote Australia, particularly, but not exclusively, got from that Federation Fund. It was a great initiative by the government. It worked extremely well indeed. There was nothing secretive about that. Where were the problems? Where were the charges? Where did you follow through? You were saying that there had been some maladministration on that fund but you have never followed it through. This is a classic example of what you do. You introduce a topic to this house and you cannot follow through with any evidence. You simply cannot do it. It is not like the days of the whiteboard—when that was all there was. When asked, the member of the day said that she had rubbed the information off the whiteboard and it was no more. That is secretive.

And what about the magnetic resonance imaging machines? What is the secrecy with respect to them? The Minister for Health and Aged Care, Dr Wooldridge, found out that an inordinate number of these machines were being ordered before the tax chopped in on them. He brought the subject up. He initiated the inquiry. He brought it in. The Labor Party, once it was initiated by Dr Wooldridge, ran with it. You picked it up and ran with it. And such is the power of the pink press that they did your bidding, and it looked as if it was your initiative. It was not.

Next you will be claiming that the subjection now of 15 people to prosecution with respect to the MRI machines was your doing. It was not. It was the doing of this government. It was the doing of the minister for health, Dr Wooldridge. It had nothing to do with you people at all—nothing at all. I would expect that some prosecutions would come out of that. And I tell you this straight: it was a rort. But it was nothing to do with the government and it was nothing to do with the initiative shown on your part. It was open government. It was our open and transparent government that allowed you to pick up on the problem with the ordering of those machines. This is a very transparent government. The people of Australia can see what we do. And do you know what? They trust us. It will be a long time before they trust you and put you back on the treasury bench. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —If ever proof was needed that the government was keeping these matters secret, it was Senator Lightfoot's speech. He clearly knows nothing about these issues at all. The MRI issue is a very serious one. It has been described by the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Dr Wooldridge, himself as a scam. His concerns about this matter were largely as a result of the Labor Party pursuing it in the parliament for the last year and pursuing it in the estimates hearings for the last year. It is only because of the pursuit of those matters by the Labor opposition that the minister has finally taken some action. We have been after him on this issue for almost a year now.

speech.para: The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron, in his question time response, accused me of hiding behind the advice of the Senate Clerk, Mr Evans—no relation, I might point out. It is important to say that I am relying on the advice of the Clerk in these issues, because he has provided a very comprehensive debunking of the government's defence for failing to produce the documents requested by the order of the Senate. There is no defence that is plausible or that can be sustained by the government for refusing to release the documents that we have requested in relation to the MRI scam. The Senate Clerk in describing the government defence in his letter of yesterday said:
. . . but new, unexplained and obscure grounds seem to be multiplying.

That is because the government is making them up on the run. We have now in the last month had five public interest immunity defences offered by the government—by Senator Newman and Senator Herron—to justify the proposition that the public interest is best served by the public not knowing what is going on, that the less the public know the more the public interest is served. That is the government's proposition. In the last month, they have offered five different grounds for that. Senator Faulkner referred to the two used by Senator Newman. Senator Herron, in his letter the other day, used a further three, including—and this is the doozey of them all; this is the real doozey—that the `Government's relationship with the profession and the future supply of information to the Government' could be prejudiced if they released information pertaining to the decision on MRI. The government's relationship with the profession could be prejudiced!

That is the basis of their decision not to release to the public the information vital to this issue. It is the government's relationship with the profession that is at the core of the problem here. They cosied up to the profession from February to May last year, in the process of making a budget decision. The minister, in his recent explanation to the parliament, said that in that period 48 new contracts for MRIs were allegedly signed. Forty-eight! That is almost as many as were in existence in the 10 or 15 years prior to that process commencing.

It is his relationship with the profession that is at the core of the problem. In the few months from February to the May budget decision, 48 new contracts for these million-dollar machines were signed. He admits a scam occurred. We knew a scam occurred, because we have been investigating this matter for almost a year now. But he admits the scam occurred because something in the relationship between the minister's office and the profession allowed it to become common knowledge that the budget decision would open up the Medicare rebate for the MRIs. Because of his concern and the public concern about this issue, the minister has been forced to remove that Medicare rebate. Those MRIs are no longer eligible for it while investigations take place.

We have been after this information since February. I want to concentrate on the minister's defence now that somehow it might prejudice the DPP investigations into MRI contracts. Not only does the Senate Clerk, Mr Evans, debunk that as total nonsense, but the HIC, the body that are investigating this matter, when I asked them about it in May of this year, made it very clear on the Hansard record that they had no problem with this information being released. Mr Watzlaff said in direct answer to a question by me:

In terms of the identified information, I wouldn't have any difficulty then because there would be no prejudice to the investigations. The investigations would be complete, the briefs would be done, the matters would be referred.

He is referring to them being referred to the DPP for prosecution. He made it clear that in his opinion in July this year that information would be able to be released to the opposition and to the public. The HIC had no problem with us having the information in about July. Here we are at the start of December and the government are inventing more and more excuses to hide the secrets of the MRI scam, to hide what happened between them and the profession that caused this scam to be perpetrated. To say that they cannot release the information to the public because it might harm their relationship with the profession is ludicrous in the extreme. (Time expired)

I too join in this debate with some delight. If ever we had a case of the pot calling the kettle black, we have it right here. I want to take the Senate back to some of the behaviour of those on the other side of the chamber that occurred in the days we were in opposition—and I particularly refer to ministers Collins and Evans—in terms of the estimates process and other matters that we dealt with at that time. They made an art form of claiming commercial in confidence, as the Hansard record will show. They did so without any excuse, just with total immunity. They would say, `Oh, that's commercial in confidence.'

The other one I should mention here was the real doozey of them all—Senator Cook. He is not with us now; he is in Seattle. The particular aspect I want to deal with was when the WTO negotiations were going on and we relentlessly pursued the then government with regard to some of the things that were going to be in that agreement, as well as the signing off on it.

talk.start.para: —Relentless is not exactly a word that comes to mind.
—They signed off on things that we never had the opportunity to scrutinise whatsoever—
—More like dead sheep.

—and we are now paying a pretty hefty price for that, particularly in the area of quarantine. It would do you good, Senator Carr, through you, Madam Deputy President, just to read a little bit of history about how this occurred and what those opposite did.

speech.para: Also with regard to the quarantine issue, there was a concern about wheat coming into this country—feed wheat, in fact. Senator Collins hid behind a veil of secrecy for many, many weeks while that particular process went on. In contrast, Dr Wooldridge has been much more open in terms of dealing with the MRI process. I say through you, Madam Deputy President, to those on the other side of the chamber that they really should look at those people of their own who have perfected this particular art.

There is one other example I can remember very clearly. It concerned one Mr Reynolds of the BLF who was allegedly travelling over to Canberra to attend particular meetings of a committee that had been set up at that particular time, I believe by Senator Cook. It was certainly Senator Cook I was dealing with in the estimates on this particular aspect. By chance I found out that, even though the meetings were being held in Canberra, Mr Reynold's destination was invariably Sydney or somewhere else. He then went back without ever getting near to where the meeting was being held. That is all on the public record now for you people to have a look at. It was denied, it was covered up and they refused to hand the information over for many, many months. Probably the class act of all was Mrs Kelly and her whiteboard and what occurred with that.

These people who come in here and throw these sorts of things across the table want to look back at a little bit of their own history and their own performance in terms of what occurred and what they did. Once again, I can refer to a particular instance involving former senator Gareth Evans when he was in charge of foreign affairs. I asked some questions about something as innocent as wool. Once again the classic answer came out, when he did not know the particular answers to my questions, `Oh, that is commercial in confidence.' It took a lot of twisting of the arm and a lot of bending of the elbow before he would come out and put those things on the table. Once again, these are pretty simple and straightforward things which you people need to have a look at.
Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Carr.

—They shout across the table. It is their usual performance in terms of dealing with this when we get up and start putting some of the facts on the table. That is their way of dealing with these particular issues. I would suggest to them that they ought to be a little bit consistent in their approach.

question.para: When it comes to withholding information from the general public, one can never ever forget what the then Prime Minister Mr Keating did with his LAW tax cuts. He took a policy into an election and he totally and absolutely deceived the Australian people. When we got back here, as those on the other side of this chamber know, he totally changed his position, reversed the decision and misled. So in terms of withholding information or misleading, we have the champions in this place. That type of behaviour comes directly and absolutely from the Labor Party, those sitting on the other side. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Isn't it interesting that some members of the coalition seem to have excellent memories that can drag up all sorts of tripe from the past, but today we saw in the chamber two frontbenchers showing their complete ignorance and lack of understanding of a very current issue, and that is the one I would like to address my comments to today. It relates to privacy and to the issue of how the privacy of consumers and citizens is protected in the information age. We have seen today reported in the newspaper and through various reports since that privacy is something that is not at the forefront of this government's agenda.

speech.para: It is quite extraordinary that, despite having made two election promises—one in 1996 and another in 1998—that this government would legislate to protect the privacy of individual information held in the commercial sector or the private sector, we are yet to see that legislation tabled in this place. What we do know—and this is an even graver indictment on the frontbenchers in this place today—is that the government has circulated a discussion paper at some length. Indeed, it was in 1998, late last year, that they circulated the national principles for the fair handling of personal information. But nearly 12 months later there is no legislation to be seen.

Despite obviously having a very clear position on this issue from the point of view of a discussion paper from the Attorney-General's Department, this government has failed to act and it has failed to legislate, exposing consumers and citizens to potentially very serious breaches of privacy. I am, of course, referring to the reportage today of an alliance between PBL and Acxiom. It is a very interesting alliance given that the new chief executive of this particular company happens to be none other than the former federal director of the Australian Liberal Party. I will come back to that point.

Let us have a look at what is being proposed here. What this company is saying is that they will store the information of 15 million Australians and they will gather it from a range of different sources. They nominate the areas. They will gather it from the electoral roll and they will gather it from credit card companies. They will gather it from a range of sources that demonstrate, for the first time that I can recall, the absolute significance of some of the corporate alliancing that is occurring in the information technology sector, the telecommunications sector, the media sector and so forth.

For the first time we have seen what I see as a confession by the CEO of this particular company as to just what depth they intend to use and manipulate personal information about citizens in this country. I will refer to Acxiom's own homepage now to show the sorts of ways they hope to use the personal information that it is suggested PBL in partnership with Acxiom will be collecting about Australian citizens:

The Acxiom Data Network, with all of its power, is only in its infancy. There are many innovations still on the way, such as the ability to integrate data directly into call centers, interactive web pages, point-of-sale applications and sales force automation software. Additionally, "push notification" will be available later this year. This technology will automatically alert subscribers when customer data has changed, keeping their data as current as possible. Subscribers will soon have the ability to build their own prospect lists directly from our InfoBase files.
If that does not make you nervous, it should.

Just about every other jurisdiction in the western world has managed to find a way to legislate quite specifically to put in place sanctions against the breach of personal information. Australia has not. My concern is that, whilst ever this government is negligent in this regard and fails to legislate for the protection of personal data held in private hands, Australian consumers and citizens will become vulnerable to a depth of manipulation that they have not given permission for and that they are not aware is actually occurring.

I believe this matter warrants the most serious consideration by the government, right now. Senator Faulkner raised in this place this afternoon the issue of the use of electoral rolls as a potential breach of section 91B(3) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. That needs to be immediately inquired into by the government to find out if that constitutes a breach of that act, and Acxiom and PBL need to be called to task. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —There has been a very wide ranging debate on the motion to take note of answers this afternoon, and it has dealt with a number of topics from secrecy and public interest immunity to Acxiom database, the production of documents relating to the MRI matter, and Senator Newman and her working documents. What has been said is that the information has been confidential and that it is likely to prejudice ongoing inquiries, but it does raise a very important principle. Public interest immunity is a matter that continually comes up in looking at documents produced for parliament and has done over the past couple of decades. It does require the reconciliation of two apparently irreconcilable issues of high policy.

speech.para: On the one hand, the principle of public policy which calls for recognition is the requirement that the parliament have access to all or any information of whatever kind which will enable it to discharge its obligations. After all, openness in government is essential to ensure representative democracy and accountable government. But this is not a complete open slather. On the other hand stands the equally important doctrine of ministerial responsibility and accountability, and a fundamental feature of responsible government is that others have to deal with government confident in the knowledge that at least some of their matters that are commercially or otherwise sensitive can be kept confidential.

Something that is completely overlooked when you have one of these debates is the risk to the public interest when it is simply left up to the political process to protect confidentiality. Politicians have no neutral evaluator role at all; they are not judges and they are not constrained in any way to conduct the balancing exercise by reference to well defined principles. Obviously, while political pressure can be brought to bear, we do have to bear in mind that you cannot underrate the importance of confidentiality in communications with government and in the decision making process. I am not mounting a play for secrecy—far from it—but those dealing with government should be able to do so with complete openness and frankness, secure in the knowledge that properly defined circumstances will allow commercially sensitive information and privacy to be protected. That does not seem to be something that comes to mind when these sorts of debates and slanging matches go across the chamber. What is the greater public interest here?

Another matter that was brought up at some length by Senator Lundy was the so-called alarm at the announcement of the establishment of the Acxiom database and the alleged threat to privacy. This is also a bit of a furphy, because the government plans to introduce a bill to amend the Privacy Act 1988, and the amendments will establish a co-regulatory framework for the protection of personal data in the private sector, and industry groups will be encouraged to develop codes of conduct for the management of personal information using the Privacy Commissioner's information privacy principles. Where a code of conduct is absent, a default legislative framework will apply.

It is important that those listening to this debate understand that the legislation will specifically apply to the collection, storage, use and disclosure of personal information. The national privacy principles have provided a default framework for the handling of personal information. There are 10 of those, and the private sector will be required to follow these standards or have its own codes that provide as much protection as the policy principles approved by the Privacy Commissioner. No-one need have any concern that there will be uncontrolled use of personal data.

If you really look at secrecy, you just have to look at what the previous Labor government did. Isn't the Beazley black hole perhaps the biggest secret of all that we have seen in this nation? If you look at the way the Labor Party have consistently withheld information on the grounds of some totally undefined principle, you can have no fear. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
