A Tasmanian group called Halo, a disgraceful hate group, tried to connect homosexuality and child sex abuse, ignoring the fact that most child abuse is male-female heterosexual and familiar. I speak from a personal perspective on this particular aspect. A friend of our family's was HIV positive and died from an AIDS-related illness in the late 1980s. At that time there was no sympathy for him in his home state of Tasmania. Had it not been for the incredible support he received from his subculture, friends and associates, he would have died a very lonely death in another state. This is not to say that World AIDS Day is the domain of a subculture but to acknowledge the astute and pivotal role the gay movement contributed to the broader public health movement in this country. The mobilisation of co-ops, 24-hour phone lines, food, information and understanding was incredible.

HIV-AIDS is not always sexually transmitted; it can also be contacted by sharing needles and equipment. There is general acceptance of legal exchange programs in Australia, often via non-criminal subterfuge where the health workers interface between the dual client demands of drug users and the general community. Courage and trust is shown by the clients who attend the exchanges knowing that they can be tagged by the moralists in our community as people who deserve the illness. The naivety of this retributive justice has nothing to do with the forgiveness mentioned in the world's spiritual writings. World AIDS Day is a time to recognise the debt we owe the many unpaid peer educators who moulded the message to allow efficient and succinct delivery of knowledge. It is about the quiet humility of thousands and thousands of volunteers such as the seamstress of the narrative quilt and the makers of the ribbons.

Unfortunately, many of our global neighbours have not had the benefit of enlightened social action. This is not only a result of economic disadvantage but also a result of historically and culturally specific mores. Thus, only by understanding and seeing the obstacles to reform can a cultural modification germinate. This realisation leads to training peer leaders. This message is then delivered to others, with cultural specific codes in place. Unfortunately, pre-existing sexual and chemical values will limit the market penetration of this vital public health strategy. In Africa, the numbers of projected HIV sufferers have been revised upwards three times in a little over five years. Male dominance and cultural adversity to condoms create optimum conditions for this viral contagion. As predicted, HIV has penetrated the Asian, American and European continents, and social rifts are occurring with outbreaks of the virus.

Without appearing morbid, a behavioural specific virus is a messenger highlighting the areas of disparity in a social and/or a fiscal sense. Other than abstinence or true monogamy, the best way to avoid the virus is the use of condoms. The acceptance of condoms in Australia is a result of mixing compassion and self-interest, opportunism and reason. Let us acknowledge the achievement of removing condoms from the embarrassed hush of the chemist's to the normality of supermarket shelves, and let us marvel at our strategy with injecting drug users that has resulted in a lower rate of infection in our prisons than in the general population of the United States.

The theme for World AIDS Day 1999 is to be 100 per cent aware, to listen to, learn from and live with people with HIV-AIDS. New trends in infection show we cannot become complacent about this virus—we are as vulnerable as ever to a resurgence of the virus. Only by reinforcing the need to listen and learn can we hope to build on our spectacular efforts of the past; and Australia does have a very safe record in this area. With the help of our gay colleagues, we will be able to continue to challenge the politics of ignorance and fear that hold within their shallow walls a recipe for a public health nightmare. Once again, we say thank you to a movement that has helped us, and continues to help us, avoid the devastation that is occurring in other nations. We ask you to reflect on this important day, 1 December, World AIDS Day.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to speak on the future of education in East Timor. Right now international aid agencies are delivering basic health and social services. Peter Hosking of the Jesuit Refugee Service says he fears that Australians may suffer compassion fatigue when the Defence Force's bills start coming in. But we need to keep education on the agenda, because without it Timor has no hope of making it in a globalised economy.

speech.para: The task facing Timorese educators is indeed daunting. The Timorese are currently faced with the question of what languages will be taught in schools and in what level of priority. They are faced with the challenge of managing the process of healing for children who have witnessed and suffered so much violence. They are faced with the prospect of no secondary schooling for at least a couple of years as adolescents help their parents in the fields to alleviate chronic food shortages. They are faced with an absence of secondary teachers. A high proportion of secondary teachers before the ballot were Indonesians, who have since fled. They are faced with literacy rates of only 44 per cent for women and 61 per cent for men. They are faced with a situation in which there are very few written resources for the teaching of Tetum, the main indigenous language, and they are faced with having to forge an entirely new education curriculum.

I hope Australians will remember the union movement here as one of the drivers for change in Timor when nearly everyone else was turning their backs. The education unions, the IEU and the AEU, are especially deserving of praise, and I want to acknowledge that tonight. They will play a major role in helping Timor build up the skills of its people. UNICEF and other agencies are delivering basic writing materials such as writing pads and pencils, but other supplies are virtually non-existent. Other equipment has always been lacking—things like glue, atlases, coloured pencils, wall charts, books and the like. Chairs and tables, for instance, have always been a rarity in schools. The unions have given generously. St Josephs Primary School in Gilgandra recently raised $600 by holding a special mass. By November, donations via the IEU will have reached $40,000. The IEU is also in the process of collecting classroom kits of materials, especially maths workbooks and other teaching aids.

Mr Patrick Lee of the New South Wales IEU recently had as a guest in his house a former assistant to the Director of the Catholic Education Office in Dili. The Catholics have taken on the responsibility of getting the education system functioning again. They have already reopened some schools. The reopening of schools has provided relief to parents and structure and routine for children, which is crucial in the aftermath of trauma. Martinio Borromeu started working on the Tetum curriculum before the ballot, and he has been trying to retrieve it from memory. When my office spoke to him, his colleagues were missing or in the hills. Borromeu said that the most pressing educational need is trauma counselling and training for teachers. He said that the Timorese cannot afford to have psychologically broken people filled with hatred and hopelessness educating the next generation of children. Teachers will have a crucial role in helping children to heal, and this need precedes training in content and pedagogy.

A core group of about 10 Timorese teachers are currently working on an emergency teachers guide to assist traumatised returning teachers to get back in front of their classes. Before the ballot, teachers were paid very little—about $20 a month, barely enough to support one person let alone teachers with dependants. Borromeu said that the remuneration caused resentment, particularly among Indonesian teachers who attracted much more money back home, and this often bred a callous attitude towards student progress, with quotes like, `It's not my problem if you can't read.' Outside Dili, principals were often not paid at all. Corporal punishment was rife, as one would expect in a society under invasion, and the military would often intervene in disputes between Indonesian teachers and families.

Class sizes were generally around 100, and seldom below 50, students. One teacher would usually take multiple year levels. Because there was a dearth of written materials, instruction was usually didactic and learning was done by rote. The Indonesian education system is often accused of encouraging conformity and mediocrity, and this duality is writ large in Indonesia's occupied territories. Families had to pay fees every month for their children's schooling. Not surprisingly, it often made more economic sense to keep children as young as five out of school and in work at home. Schooling usually took place in shifts.

The way forward for education in Timor will not be an easy one, given this scenario. The question of language is a vexing one. Tetum will presumably be the first language taught in schools, but there are very few written resources. The Mary MacKillop Institute in Sydney has been working for some time on developing curriculum materials in Tetum and has so far got to middle primary level. Before the ballot, it was decided that Timor's future lay in making Portuguese the main second language taught in schools. I have been told that this is now a fairly shaky proposition. English as a second language is in demand. It is the international language of commerce and the language of ASEAN. The place of bahasa, the Indonesian language, is unclear. There is recognition, though, that the many students who have been taught mainly in bahasa cannot be abandoned. There is also a deep hostility towards the Indonesian language remaining even for a transition period. The Mary MacKillop Institute told the recent Senate inquiry into Timor:

In the present situation, East Timorese children entering a classroom find themselves in a learning context that is foreign—the only language allowed to be spoken and used in the classroom is that of the foreign invaders. . . . Psychologists who specialise in learning theory tell us that, beyond mild levels, fear inhibits learning. The trauma that many children have experienced at the hands of the invaders must surely put a psychological block and hinder the East Timorese children's learning in their language.

Two years ago AusAID rejected the institute's funding for classroom and curriculum materials. Another agency was told there would be no funding for first language learning or ESL support because Portuguese was being touted as a replacement for bahasa. AusAID's consistent refusal to fund educational projects in Timor should be a source of national shame. Bear in mind that most schools are lucky to have a blackboard. The institute's massive literacy and translation work has been kept going by the Catholic Church and its congregations. When one of the sisters visited Timor earlier this year, people were dying of malnutrition. Children were travelling hours on foot to get to school. Some children were working punishing hours to keep their younger siblings at school.

One agency has touted a demonstration school model where teachers would combine on-the-job experience with their training. This would release badly needed teachers immediately. Post-independence, ESL support will be vital as well as first language learning and language laboratories. Peter Hosking says that Timor will quite capably run its own school system but, to do this, it needs help in teacher training and curriculum development. His suggestions include sending Australian teachers to Timor. State education departments and non-government systems could, for instance, provide teachers with leave to do this. Or we could give Timorese teachers scholarships to study in Australia. Perhaps if we had treated the Timorese asylum seekers better we would have had some qualified teachers ready to return.

The fact that Timorese children seeking asylum in Australia are excluded from TAFE, apprenticeships and traineeships after year 12 is disgraceful. They are also barred from university as they are considered to be over seas students and therefore full fee paying. David Peace, a Melbourne teacher, recently wrote:
I feel ashamed when I try to explain this policy to the dedicated, enthusiastic young people who have chosen Australia for their home after escaping terror and tyranny in their homeland.

Asylum seekers are generally on protection visas, which do allow them to access state primary and secondary education. But these children start school in a language vacuum. Many parents speak Hakka, a Chinese language, while the children speak Tetum. Neither is a written language and this makes it very difficult for parents to help with literacy enrichment. Children routinely miss out on extracurricular activities because of their parents' poverty, unless they go to a particularly understanding and proactive school.

I would argue that Mr Ruddock should also rethink his shameful approach to sending home with just a bag of rice, a blanket and a sheet of plastic refugees who came from East Timor during the conflict. Children in these circumstances will not have access to schools back in East Timor, let alone health services, adequate food or shelter. They do want to return, but now is not the right time. In my view, Australia has a dual moral obligation to the Timorese: we must help with rebuilding its educational institutions and we must abolish the education trap that we have created for Timorese asylum seekers in this country.

talk.start.para: —On 16 July 1945 a group of scientists from both Europe, including Britain, and the United States detonated the first nuclear device in the world. That was called the `Manhattan Project'. A direct result of that was that an American aircraft called the Enola Gay dropped nuclear devices on both Nagasaki and Hiroshima in Japan. These were exploded somewhat above the cities and devastated them from that height. When the war in the Pacific ended, the benefits of the nuclear age, or the atomic age as it was then termed, were turned to peaceful uses. Today there are 445 nuclear power stations around the world. One of those nuclear power stations malfunctioned in Russia, at Chernobyl, some 10 years ago and put the other nuclear power stations in the rest of the world on notice. Since then there has been a second generation of nuclear power plants, some of which are under construction now. Notwithstanding that, nuclear power is still the safest, most efficient and least damaging environmentally to this world that we live in. That is indisputable. But we have to ask the question: what are we going to do with the waste that is accumulating around the world and should Australia participate in that? Sweden, for instance, generates 50 per cent of its power from nuclear energy; France generates 79 per cent of its power from nuclear energy; in the United States, 19 per cent of the power is nuclear; and 17 per cent of power throughout the world is generated by nuclear power. Seventy kilos of uranium feeding a 1,000-megawatt power plant needs the equivalent on the same basis per day of 8,800 tonnes of coal—that is, it takes 8,800 tonnes of coal to power a 1,000-megawatt power station, or 70 kilos of uranium.

speech.para: Australia has about 30 per cent of the world's known low cost recoverable uranium and about 12 per cent of the world's exports. Canada has about 12 per cent of the world's reserves and 28 per cent of the world's exports. Canada is opening up two new uranium mines this year that will produce in aggregate 8,000 tonnes of uranium or U-308—yellowcake. By comparison, both Jabiluka and Ranger together will be producing only 6,000 tonnes. During the Whitlam period, from 1972-75, no figures were kept on the export of uranium, but Australia produced 6,415 tonnes in 1997-98, which was valued at $288 million. With 12 per cent of the world's exports of uranium, one has to ask: what sort of responsibility do we have with respect to that waste? Australia has invented a method of safe, long-term and cheap storage. It is called synroc. It is a method that has already been tested and one that is operating in the United States, the United Kingdom, France and, we hope, Russia.

Russia is a continuous worry to the rest of the world. It is sometimes thought—not without some evidence—that Russia will become the repository of the world's uranium power stations or nuclear power station waste. I wonder whether that is not going to be a mistake. On the other hand, Australia is an area the same size landmass as the mainland of the United States but with 19 million people instead of 260 million—an area where we have undoubted geological stability, an area where we have political stability, and an area that is inviting to countries such as the United Kingdom, which has deep storage; France, where, as I said, nearly 80 per cent of its power comes from nuclear sources, and other areas such as Holland, Sweden, Switzerland, Japan—all small countries by our standards—that do not have the advantages we have here.

We could say, `Not in my back yard thank you,' and that is something I understand. But in a global environment—we have the Minister for Trade, Mark Vaile, at this moment attending the Seattle round of the World Trade Organisation—we have to ask ourselves: is it truly a global village? If it is, then we have a responsibility at least to return the waste that is derived from the uranium that we export. It may be that we have a larger responsibility than that, given the isolation as well as the geological stability and the political stability of this continent of Australia. We have the oldest of all rocks in the world, apart from Greenland—3.8 billion years old, and some of those rocks are in Western Australia. We have areas like the Great Sandy Desert and the Great Victoria Desert just north of the Nullarbor Plains that fit in that category of political and geological stability.

The uranium atom is highly mobile in water; that is, when it is mixed with H2O it moves along just slighter slower than water moves. Therefore, if there is waste storage in Australia, that needs to be taken cognisance of. If it does not go there, are we happy to say that it should go to Russia—not geologically stable, with permafrost and with more water than any other country on earth? And I understand Russia has suggested that it lease enriched uranium to consumers in these second generation nuclear power stations.

Or will it go to some developing country near Australia? Will it, for instance, go to cash strapped Indonesia? That is on our doorstep. Will it go to the emerging nation of East Timor? That is on our doorstep. Will it go to Papua New Guinea? That is on our doorstep. Will it go to Vanuatu or to any other geologically unstable and politically unstable countries that surround the northern periphery of Australia that are much closer to those of us in the northern part of Western Australia, the northern part of Queensland and the Northern Territory than Lucas Heights is to Perth, Adelaide, Alice Springs, Melbourne or the cherub state, as I call it, of Tasmania?

Do we have a responsibility to ensure that the reserves of 629,000 tonnes of recoverable uranium are returned to this nation? Can we say that an export of $288 million, as another argument, should not be exported and we should close down all of the uranium mines in Australia, like the silly Mr Tony O'Grady, the Minister for Mines in Queensland, has done.

talk.start.para: —Order! Please do not reflect upon a member of another chamber.

—He has closed down mines up there and prevented one mine at least from going ahead, which could have returned to Queenslanders $3.6 billion over its life. If we did stop producing uranium in Australia, would it stop the production of uranium throughout the world? Of course it would not.

speech.para: Under the three-mine policy of the Hawke government—effectively a two-mine policy—the biggest uranium mine in the world became the Rossing mine in Namibia owned by Rio Tinto Zinc. It will not stop the production of uranium. We can make a stand, but at what cost? It is a vexing issue. It does genuinely cause people problems. But I know in my own heart, with my own experience in exploration—looking for uranium and working with uranium ores—that we do have an answer to it. It is about time we exploited that; it is about time that it was explained in a rational manner to people so that this global village we live in can be a safer place for us all. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 12 August 1999:

question.para: (1) What screening process is used to assess the airworthiness of second-hand aircraft parts.
(2) (a) What organisation is responsible for undertaking the above assessments; and (b) who is responsible for policing the screening process.
(3) Did a licensed aircraft maintenance engineer discover a major crack in the main rotor grip in a helicopter at a Melbourne airport in early 1998.
(4) When was that incident reported to the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA).
(5) Did the then chair of CASA, Mr Dick Smith write to the engineer commending him on his work and direct CASA to investigate the incident.
(6) Was that investigation carried out by the CASA Sydney office; if so: (a) who was responsible for that investigation; and (b) what was the outcome.

(7) Was the incident referred to the CASA Canberra office in July or August 1998, specifically the office of Air Safety Compliance, for further investigation; if not: (a) on what date was the matter referred to the Canberra office; (b) who undertook the further investigation; and (c) what was the outcome.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) has provided the following information:
(1) The general scheme for controlling the installation and use of aircraft components in maintenance can be found in the provisions of the Civil Aviation Regulations (1988) listed below.

The scheme is focused on the individual performing the maintenance. This allows the regulations to cater for the complete range of operations within Australian aviation. Under the regulations and general exemption, the responsibility for ensuring that an aircraft component installed or used in an aircraft meets the legal requirements rests with the person responsible for the installation and use of the component.
Regulation 42W—Installation and use of aircraft components in maintenance of Australian aircraft in Australian territory.

The regulations do not specifically refer to aircraft components as "second hand". Rather, under reg 42W, provisions are made that a person may not replace an aircraft component with another aircraft component unless it meets the conditions set out in the regulation.

The provisions of reg 42W are extensive, and specific direction is given as to how components are to be identified and certified. Under each of the provisions of the regulation, direction is given as to how to treat items that have undergone maintenance.

The only provision that allows the use of components removed or salvaged from other aircraft where no maintenance has been carried out is found in reg 42W(2)(c). In this case, subject to some qualifications in Reg 42W, the component may be installed if it is not damaged and complies with the manufacturer's specifications.
Regulation 42X—Use of aircraft materials in maintenance—Australian aircraft in Australian territory.
This regulation contains provisions similar to, though not identical with, those in reg 42W applying to the use of materials in aircraft maintenance.
Regulation 42Y- Time-lifed components—exemption from supply under cover of document requirements.

Time-lifed components can be exempted from the requirements of reg 42W(4)(a) and (b) if a person satisfies CASA or an authorised person that there is a complete record of airworthiness history available.
Exemption Number 5/1992

While the basic structure of the scheme to control the use of components and materials is contained in the regulations mentioned above there is also a general exemption, number 5/1992, that provides some relief against these requirements under specific conditions.

(2) (a) The regulations clearly state that the ultimate responsibility rests with the person replacing, installing or using an aircraft component. In larger organisations, such as a well-established airline, it is usual to find systems set up to deal with the storage and identification of components. In these cases it is normal to find procedures for these functions in the organisation's manuals. In smaller operations, the Licensed Aircraft Maintenance Engineer performing or certifying the work would hold individual responsibility. In all cases the regulations provide that the "person" replacing, installing or using an aircraft component is responsible for ensuring that it meets the legal requirements set out in the legislation.

(b)Primary responsibility for ensuring compliance rests with the person replacing, installing or using an aircraft component. Methods for ensuring compliance would normally be documented in the operators' manuals. As part of its surveillance functions, CASA conducts audits of holders of Certificates of Approval to determine if the holder has acted in accordance with the regulations.
(3) A licensed aircraft maintenance engineer discovered the crack in the main rotor grip in a helicopter at a Melbourne airport on 4 December 1997.
(4) The fault was reported to CASA in a Major Defect Report on 5 December 1997.
(5) A letter of commendation was sent to the engineer by the (then) CASA Chairman on 19 December 1997. The Chairman also asked CASA to investigate the matter.

Following a detailed technical investigation into the mechanics and history of the material failure, the General Manager Airworthiness, recommended, in December 1997, that an investigation be conducted.
(6) An investigation was carried out by the CASA Sydney Office.
(a) An aviation safety investigator from CASA's (then) South-East Region was responsible for the investigation.

(b) The investigation revealed that the most obvious offence, relating to the installation and use of aircraft components in maintenance of Australian Aircraft under reg 42W, was statute-barred by the time the crack was discovered in the main rotor yoke. Under Civil Aviation Regulation (1988) 296, there is a three-year limit on commencing of prosecution action and that time runs from the date of commission of the offence, not from when the offence was discovered.

The only way that prosecution for an offence could have been commenced after the discovery of the crack is if the prosecution could have been brought under a provision of the Civil Aviation Act 1988 which provided for a penalty exceeding 6 months imprisonment as under section 15B of the Crimes Act 1901 such prosecution may be brought at any time after the commission of the offence. In this context, consideration was given to proceeding with an action under section 20AA(4) of the Civil Aviation Act 1988 on the basis that, because the maintenance release was defective, the aircraft had flown without a valid maintenance release being in force. Such an offence carries a maximum penalty of 2 years imprisonment under subsection 20AA(5) of the Civil Aviation Act 1988.

It was decided not to proceed with an action on this basis as it would have been tenuously based and would have represented an inappropriate use of the legislation to attempt to achieve a prosecution. Under section 20AA(5) the offence in section 20AA(4) is directed to the `owner, operator, hirer (not being the Crown) or pilot of an aircraft' rather than the person performing the maintenance. As those parties did not know about the defective part they could not have `knowingly or recklessly' operated the aircraft in contravention of section 20AA(4).
There was, therefore, no way in which CASA could instigate prosecution action under the Civil Aviation Act or Regulations.
(a) At the request of the Assistant Director, Aviation Safety Compliance the case was reviewed in Canberra in February 1999.
(b) The review was undertaken by an aviation safety investigator not directly associated with the initial investigation.

(c) The review supported the judgement of the initial investigator that a prosecution could not be commenced because of the three-year time limit imposed under Civil Aviation Regulation 296 and the absence of facts providing a solid basis for the prosecution of an offence under the Civil Aviation Act 1988.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

answer.para: The Civil Aviation Safety Authority has provided the following information:

(1) The Program Advisory Panel (PAP) was established to provide industry and consumer oversight to the Regulatory Framework and Regulatory Role Programs in the CASA reviews. Panel members were also divided into two Sub-committees + the Regulatory Framework Sub-committee and the Regulatory Role Sub-committee + to participate in, and facilitate the work of, Technical Committees and Project Teams in ensuring that the objectives of the review programs were met.

As a matter of practice, the Panel rarely met in sub-committees but the two sub-committee chairmen, Capt. W Hamilton (Regulatory Framework) and Capt D Wiltshire (Regulatory Role) liaised closely with the Program Managers to monitor progress and ensured adequacy of industry and consumer representation on individual projects.
(2) (a) The Program Advisory Panel was established in September 1996 and met formally for the first time on 15 October 1996.

(b) The Panel was initially established by the then Minister for Transport and Regional Development (the Hon. John Sharp MP) and given an extended term by the succeeding Minister, the Hon. Mark Vaile MP.
(c) See Attachment A.
(d) See Attachment A.

(e) The Panel, through its Chairman, provided industry advice to the Director of Aviation Safety, and monthly progress reports and recommendations direct to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development.
(3) (a) The Panel met 17 times between 1996 and 1998, with the first meeting held in October 1996 and the last meeting held in June 1998.

(b) The Panel delivered a report on its work to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, the Hon Mark Vaile MP, on 28 November 1997. The report is titled: Report to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development from the Program Advisory Panel regarding its oversight of the CASA Regulatory Framework and Regulatory Role Programs in the CASA Reviews.

(4) A copy of the report referred to in the answer to Question 3(b) has been provided to the Table Office. Minutes of the Panel meetings are available upon request. Minutes of the Panel's meetings and its report were earlier made available on the CASA website.

(5) The panel recommended that all dispensations or exemptions from CASA regulations be publicly disclosed. This approach is being followed in the Regulatory Framework Program. In its deliberations the Panel also canvassed the publication of current dispensations, exemptions etc. but CASA's advice was that the sheer volume of the materials involved, and the difficulty of locating all of them, made the task impossible. The Panel's views on this issue are set out at paragraph 7.6 of its report.
All exemptions issued by CASA since 1 July 1997 are available for download from the CASA web site.
(6) (a) The Panel discussed and sought CASA action on the issues of dispensation and exemption at its third meeting, which was held on 17 December 1996.

(b) The Panel's recommendation was adopted by CASA and implemented with the establishment on 1 July 1997 of a public register recording details of dispensations, exemptions etc and the reasons for which they were granted.

(c) The Panel considered that publication would not only provide for openness and transparency, particularly where operators are in competition, but would also enable an assessment to be made of the relevance of current regulatory provisions. The Panel took the view that an excessive number of waivers with respect to specific regulations would suggest that those regulations were in need of amendment.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Transition Rules
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1564)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: With reference to section 6 of A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax Transition) Act 1999, which specifies `timing of supply' rules in order to determine whether the goods and services tax (GST) is payable on transactions that span the 1 July 2000 implementation date: Given that under section 6(3) of the transitional rules real property, (ie. real estate) is taken to be provided at the time that the property is `first made available to the recipient':
(1) For the purposes of the transition rules, when is real property taken to be `made available to the recipient' for GST purposes?

(2) If a taxpayer signs a contract for the purchase of real property before 1 July 2000 and settlement arises after 1 July 2000, is GST payable where, under the contract for sale, the purchaser has the right to occupy the dwelling before 1 July 2000?

(3) Where a taxpayer leases a property from 1 July 1998 and, after leasing the real property for 3 years the lessee and the owner of the property enter into a contract for sale which is signed and settled on 3 July 2001, does GST apply to the sale of the real property? (Note: The recipient, (ie. the lessee) who purchased the real property from the owner has had the property `made available' from 1 July 1998, that is, commencement of the lease, which is pre-GST).

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Under the GST transition rules, real property is taken to be `made available to the recipient' when equitable ownership or possession of the property is transferred, that is, upon settlement. At settlement the recipient of the supply of real property has full use and enjoyment of the property.

(2) If the real property is supplied at the time of settlement, GST will be payable on the supply where settlement arises after 1 July 2000, even if the contract for the purchase of the real property has been signed before 1 July 2000. Whether real property is `made available to the recipient' requires more than a right to occupy or use the property in some limited way before 1 July 2000. It requires that the recipient must have full use and enjoyment of the property.

(3) The sale of the property on 3 July 2001 would be subject to GST, assuming it is property that does not qualify for input tax treatment (eg, established residential dwellings) or GST-free treatment (eg, certain farm land). If taxable, GST may be calculated on the full price of the property or according to the GST's margin system. Where a registered business purchases a property fully taxed, it will be able to claim an input tax credit for the tax payable thereby making the purchase effectively tax free. Under the margin system the GST would be calculated on the gross margin, that is, the sale price minus the value of the property at 1 July 2000.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Business Number: Use of Information Supplied
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1565)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: Will the Australian Taxation Office and other government agencies be able to use the information that is provided by taxpayers in applying for Australian Business Number (ABN) Registration, for audit purposes.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The information supplied to the ABN Registrar for the purpose of obtaining an ABN will only consist of basic identity details such as name and address information, details about the activity the person or organisation is engaged in, and the person or organisation's Tax File Number (TFN).

With the exception of the TFN, this information will be publicly available to anyone requiring it, including government agencies. There are privacy requirements in relation to the TFN and it will not be available to the public or government agencies through the Australian Business Register. The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) will already possess the correct TFN information of entities registering for the ABN because the ATO is responsible for issuing TFNs.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Australian Business Number
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1566)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: Are contractors who operate in an employee-like way and who operate through a company, going to be automatically entitled to register for an Australian Business Number and for goods and services tax purposes.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The Australian Business Number (ABN) has been introduced to assist businesses, non profit organisations and other enterprises by making it easier for them to deal with government agencies. This will be achieved by reducing the need to provide the same information more than once and by making it possible to obtain more comprehensive information from government at fewer locations.
Eligibility for an ABN is not restricted to particular entity types, such as a company or a partnership, and is not restricted to business.

To obtain an ABN an individual, association, company, partnership or trust will need to satisfy the Registrar that it is carrying on an enterprise. Enterprise can be any one of a range of activities, including an activity conducted in the form of a business, in the form of an adventure or in the nature of trade, by religious and charitable institutions and by government bodies.
Individuals who are subject to the new PAYG withholding system, such as common law employees and contractors engaged in labour hire arrangements cannot obtain an ABN.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Property Developers
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1568)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: If a property developer sells a property via an auction and, under the terms and conditions of the auction, the purchaser must provide a 10 per cent deposit, when is the property developer obliged to remit the goods and services tax in respect of the sale of the real property under Division 29 of A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax) Act 1999.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The property developer must account for all the GST on a taxable supply in the tax period in which any of the consideration is received for the supply (or in the tax period in which the invoice for the supply is issued, if that is earlier).

Under Division 99 of A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax) Act 1999), a security deposit is not treated as being consideration for a supply (and hence not subject to GST) unless the deposit is forfeited or is applied towards the consideration.

If the deposit is forfeited or is applied towards the consideration, GST is paid on the amount of the deposit. The GST is attributed to the tax period in which the deposit is forfeited or is applied toward the consideration.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: (1) Is it a fact that goods and services tax (GST) invoices with a value of less than $1,000 will not have to include the buyer's name, Australian Business Number (ABN) or address; if so, why.
(2) Will the non-inclusion of the ABN and other details make it easier to defraud the GST system.

(3) What is there to stop someone disguising a transaction, for example, a transaction worth $5,000 to appear as 10 transactions worth $500 each, in order to avoid having to put the buyer's ABN on the GST tax invoice.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The GST Act requires a tax invoice to show the ABN of the issuing entity (this will usually be the vendor but in the case of a recipient generated invoice it will be the purchaser), the GST inclusive price of a taxable supply, and other information specified in the regulations.

Included in the additional information specified in the GST regulations is a requirement for an invoice to show the purchaser's name and address or name and ABN, if the value of the invoice exceeds $1,000.

The difference in the invoice information requirements reflects a practical approach designed to accommodate smaller business transactions. For example, retail sales documents do not generally record purchaser or quantity details.

It is not considered that these measures will make it easier to defraud the GST system. The information provided on invoices will be sufficient to identify transactions and the parties involved where it is necessary to do so.

subdebateinfo.title: Taxation: Pay As You Go System
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1580)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: (1) What will be the impact on small business cash flows as a result of the Government's proposed Pay As You Go (PAYG) system.
(2) Will the PAYG system result in the tax liability of many small businesses being brought forward, as opposed to the current system of small business tax collections.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) and (2) Sole traders currently pay their quarterly provisional tax instalments on 1 September, 1 December, 1 March and 1 June. Each instalment is paid inside the quarter, for example the instalment for the quarter ending 30 June is paid on 1 June, before all the income for the quarter is earned. In addition, all of the instalments are made within the income year. Under PAYG they will pay quarterly instalments 50 days later on 21 October, 21 January, 21 April and 21 July. All instalments will be payable after the quarter with the final instalment not due until after the end of the income year.

Companies currently pay their instalments later, and at different times depending on their tax liability. Small tax companies pay one instalment on 15 December, 6 months after the income year, and the balance of their tax on 15 March 9 months after the income year. Medium tax companies make quarterly instalments on 1 June, 1 September, 1 December and 1 March. Only one instalment falls within the income year in the final month of June. Large tax companies pay two of their four instalments within the income year, their instalments are due on 1 March, 1 June, 1 September and 1 December.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Computer System Costs
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1593)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: With reference to the report in Inside Canberra that Mr Neil Wickenden, a business tax partner at HLB Mann Judd, has been advising clients that it will cost them up to $4000 in new hardware and software to become goods and services tax (GST) ready: Does the Government agree that it will cost small businesses up to $4000 to become GST ready; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: No. Each business that registers for the GST will need to make its own decision about how to operate in the GST environment. Some businesses might decide to utilise existing systems (computerised or paper based) and thus not incur capital costs for GST start up. Other businesses may decide to purchase new systems, including new hardware and/or software. Any capital costs will vary and reflect the needs of the businesses.

Businesses which have computers but not accounting software might use the free electronic cash book which the ATO will send to all GST registrants. Certain software companies have announced they will provide free upgrades of popular accounting packages.

Should businesses decide to purchase new hardware and software, the Government has allowed businesses with annual turnover up to $10 million to claim an immediate tax write-off on computer hardware and software (and other items) purchased before 1 July 2000 to prepare for the GST. In addition, the Government is providing direct assistance to small and medium businesses from the $500 million GST start-up assistance funds to help them prepare for the GST.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 30 September 1999:

question.para: With reference to educational institutions which operated under the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Act 1991 and the Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students, and in regards to the collapse of the National Business Management College: (a) how many students were enrolled at the college at the time of its collapse; (b) how many students was the department aware of at the time of its collapse; (c) (i) how many of those students have been located, and (ii) what is the location of those students now; (d) how many students has the department failed to locate; (e) what has been done, and what is currently being done, to trace missing students; (f) (i) how many breaches of visa requirements has the department identified, and (ii) what actions have been taken; (g) how many students have been deported; and (h) what records of student enrolments and attendance has the department recovered.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (a) The exact number of overseas students enrolled at National Colleges of Australia Pty Ltd (NCA) t/a National Business Management College (Australia), National Senior School (Australia) and National English College (Australia) at the time of its closure on 9 June 1999 is not known, but it appears that 321 were definitely enrolled. While NCA was required to maintain records of enrolment, the Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs (DETYA) is not. According to advice from NCA's solicitor and the liquidator appointed to wind-up the affairs of NCA, electronic and paper student records had been deleted or removed prior to the closure. The maximum enrolment capacity at NCA at the time of its closure was 2,180 students.

(b) DETYA is not required to maintain records of students enrolments. The Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (DIMA) provides weekly updates of student visas issued. On 9 June when NCA closed, the report generated from this DIMA data indicated 639 visas had been issued to students wanting to attend NCA. A subsequent examination of available NCA records, provided a list of 672 overseas students who were possibly at NCA at the time it closed. This figure has since increased to 735 students believed to have been either attending NCA or included amongst NCA's records at the time of its collapse. The increased figure resulted from:
. a number of students not recorded on the original list contacted DETYA;
. local and overseas agents advised DETYA of details of students they had recruited for NCA;
. and many providers who had enrolled ex-NCA students advised DETYA of the details of these students.

(c) (i) DETYA is not required to maintain student contact details but has been able to obtain them for 340 of the possible 735 students. DIMA advises a total of 257 students have contacted DIMA to make applications for further student visas in relation to their studies and have since undertaken studies with different education providers. In addition 127 students were identified as having changed provider prior to the collapse of NCA.
(ii) Of the 340 students for whom DETYA has obtained contact details, there are 22 students who paid money to NCA but were not granted a visa to enter Australia.

(d) DIMA advises that of the 735 student names that appear on the consolidated list of students, a sample indicates that 20% are not recorded on DIMA records, meaning that they have not entered Australia, and about 15% have already left Australia. A further 35% have transferred institution and obtained new visas from DIMA, and 20% are known to have changed institution but have not been required to obtain replacement visas. 4% have had their visas cancelled. Approximately 6% have moved interstate to study, have applied for other visas, or form part of a small residual group who are in breach of their visa conditions and are yet to be located.
(e) In addition to the actual inspection of paper files described in the response to (b) above, DETYA has written to:
. individual students for whom addresses have been available;

. the Australian Council for Private Education and Training (ACPET), the Australian Council of Independent Vocational Colleges (ACIVC), the ELICOS Association Ltd and to individual education providers registered on CRICOS to both seek their assistance in placing ex-NCA students and to advise DETYA of when and if ex-NCA students enrol in other institutions; and
. agents in Australia and overseas seeking information as to the whereabouts of students for whom they may have arranged enrolment with NCA.
DETYA continues to pursue these avenues and is in frequent contact with DIMA, exchanging and updating information as it becomes available.

DIMA advises that students visaed prior to December 1998 were not required to advise DIMA of a change of provider. From this date legislation was introduced requiring students to obtain permission from DIMA to change provider in the first 12 months (or the duration of course, if less than 12 months).

DIMA advises that the students enrolled at NCA at the time of its collapse who have not contacted DIMA and are in breach of their visa conditions are currently the subject of Compliance activity, with a view to cancelling their visas and removing them from Australia.

(f) (i) DETYA does not maintain this information, however DIMA has advised that for the period 30/9/98 + 30/9/99, a total of 26 NCA students had their visas cancelled, generally for failing to meet their course requirements and for working in excess of their allowable hours (20 hours/week). Additionally , a number of NCA students who have failed to contact DIMA may be liable for visa cancellation, detention and removal.

(ii) Such action lies outside DETYA's portfolio responsibilities, however DIMA has advised that for the period 30/9/98 + 30/9/99, a total of 26 NCA students had their visas cancelled, generally for failing to meet their course requirements and for working in excess of their allowable hours (20 hours/week). Additionally , a number of NCA students who have failed to contact DIMA may be liable for visa cancellation, detention and removal.

(g) DETYA does not maintain this information and DIMA has advised this information is not available as the DIMA statistical reporting systems are not able to provide data on removals (or voluntary departures) by educational institution.

(h) None. All documents and information holdings of NCA are held by the liquidator appointed to wind-up the affairs of NCA. The liquidator has advised that some electronic records have been deleted and that there is evidence that paper records had been removed before NCA closed.

answer.para: (1) The allocation of FSS Projects in Schools is outlined in the following table.
FIGURES AS AT 11 OCTOBER 1999

(2) (a), (b) and (c) The Commonwealth is funding a National Evaluation of the FSS program to be undertaken between December 1999 to December 2000. answer.para: (b) It is not possible to ascertain in detail how States handle their internal financial administration. It is not unusual for education authorities to utilise their own sources of funding in anticipation of Commonwealth or other sources of funding.

(c) Prior to the finalisation of the enabling legislation, the Commonwealth and State/Territory FSS Steering Committees undertook extensive consultations to develop submissions for projects in schools which meant that States/Territories had a clear picture early on of the type of initiatives they would be implementing for FSS. (a) and (b) The FSS Program is currently legislated for completion in December 2000. Any future funding for the program is a decision for Government in the context of Budget considerations.

(c) State Governments, of course, have the primary responsibility for meeting the needs of students at risk of leaving school. For its part, the Commonwealth provides support for at risk youth aged 15 years and over through the Job Placement Employment and Training Program, which provides holistic assistance and support to these young people.

The Government is concerned to improve the support provided to young people during their transition to independence more broadly, and to strengthen pathways for young people who do not, or are not likely to, go straight from school to further education and training or full-time employment, including those at risk of not completing their secondary education.

The Government has recently appointed a taskforce to recommend on the scope and direction of a Youth Pathways Action Plan to improve outcomes for young people by strengthening existing pathways for young people, and especially those at risk; improving early assistance for young people, before they reach crisis point; helping those who are in crisis situations to quickly move out of them; strengthening families' and communities' capacity to help young people; and expanding opportunities for young people to participate in the economic and social life of their communities.

The Taskforce includes representatives from the community, business and academic sectors, as well as both State and Commonwealth Governments, reflecting the emphasis the Government places on the need for broad community partnerships to strengthen pathways for young people. The Taskforce has been asked to report by March 2000.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, upon notice, on 12 October 1999:

question.para: (1) Does the Government have any policy as to whether Basslink should be operated in a mono-pole or bi-pole configuration.
(2) If Basslink is operated in a mono-pole configuration, what will be the effects on:
(a) buried metal in the vicinity of any land terminal (and extending to what radius);
(b) steel pipeline used to bring natural gas assure;
(c) steel wire armoured Telstra fibre-optic cables crossing Bass Strait;
(d) the shark fishing industry; and
(e) vessels relying on magnetic compasses for navigation in Bass Strait.
(3) Which authorities advise the Commonwealth, Victorian and Tasmanian Governments about the possible effects of operating Basslink in a mono-pole configuration.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Commonwealth supports the interconnection of State electricity systems, subject to the necessary economic and environmental assessments. New interconnections are an important means of maximising the benefits from the National Electricity Market (NEM) which has now been operating successfully for almost 11 Months.
Basslink will enable Tasmania to join the NEM.
Basslink is also a key element of the Tasmanian Government's energy strategy and is considered by the government as a critical factor in the State's future economic development.
For example Basslink should:
. improve the security of electricity supply and reduce the exposure of Tasmania's Hydro electricity supply to drought conditions;
. provide Tasmania with access to electricity at prices determined competitively in the NEM;
. provide a means by which electricity generated in Tasmania can be sold into the NEM and provide a new source of peak generating capacity in the NEM;
. ensure through a competitive selection process the cost of Basslink to users is minimalised; and
. ensure that the returns to from State-owned electricity businesses are maximised.

Basslink is being presented by the Tasmanian government as a commercial opportunity in the NEM to be constructed by the private sector as a build, own and operate project. A short list of three proponents has been selected. It is understood that the preferred proponent is to be selected by next February with the objective that Basslink will be completed in 2002.

As Senator Brown would appreciate, a project of this nature is required to undergo a rigorous assessment and approval process where all critical elements of the proposal are examined at length. In this case, it has been agreed that a Combined (Commonwealth, Tasmanian and Victorian Government) Assessment and Approvals Process (CAAP) will be undertaken to jointly assess this proposal.

The Commonwealth does not have a policy as to whether Basslink should be operated in mono-pole or bi-pole configuration. That decision would be expected to hinge on the outcome of the assessment and approval process.
Environment Australia will be responsible for coordinating Commonwealth involvement in the CAAP.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on Friday, 22 October 1999:

question.para: With reference to educational institutions that operate under the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Act 1991 and the Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students (CRICOS):
(1) Has the department crosschecked the names of owners, operators or managers of these institutions to ensure that they are not also registered immigration agents; if not, why not.

(2) Does the department regularly monitor the numerous magazine advertisements, both in Australia and abroad, which openly promote student visas as an easy and cheap means of entering Australia; if not, why not.
(3) Has the department detected any breaches of the law by providers or their agents that advertise student visas as a way of entering Australia.
(4) What administrative and audit mechanisms are employed by the department to confirm actual enrolment numbers and student attendance at each college.
(5) How does the department ensure that maximum enrolment entitlements are not breached by students transferring between colleges while they are in Australia.
(6) How does the department track and monitor attendance of students who transfer between colleges within Australia.
(7) How many institutions in the past 12 months have exceeded their maximum student numbers.

(8) (a) How many staff within the International, Analysis and Evaluation Division of the department in 1996 were working on the administration of the Act; (b) how many are currently working on these tasks; (c) what are their specific duties; and (d) how many staff are assigned to undertake compliance audits.

(9) Given that the Minister has stated that 11 colleges have fallen into difficulties since 1994 and that 9 providers have had their registration suspended or cancelled or been forced to close in the past 12 months, what action has the Government taken to reduce this alarming escalation in college failures.

(10) What, and how many, investigations has the department undertaken over the past 12 months for: (a) misleading or deceptive conduct; (b) enrolling students for whom no registration has been given; and (c) failure to notify the department of breaches of attendance requirements.

(11) What complaints about the operations of these colleges has the Government received from: (a) overseas governments or agencies; (b) parents of students studying in Australia; (c) overseas students studying in Australia; (d) industry representative bodies; and (e) other providers operating under the Act

(12) With reference to the answer to question on notice no 1361 (Senate Hansard , 12 October 1999, p9147): (a) why was Lloyds International College, CRICOS provider number 01942A, not included in the list of colleges supplied in answer to (4); and (b) are there other CRICOS-listed colleges which are not included in that list.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: This question is similar to question on notice no 1361 (Senate Hansard, 12 October 1999) number 4 "Can a list be provided of non-exempt, CRICOS-listed providers under the Act which are owned, operated or managed by providers who are or have been registered migration agents."
The response was:

"DETYA does not hold details of the "owners", "operators" or "managers" of providers. The Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students (CRICOS) lists a provider's "Principal Executive Officer" (PEO).

Only one PEO is listed on the Register of Migration Agents maintained by the Migration Agents Registration Authority + Mr Kofi Ameyaw Osei of Caprock International Ltd, trading as Lloyds International College, CRICOS provider number 01942A."

In order to identify "owners", "operators" or "managers", DETYA would have to undertake individual company searches with the Australian Securities Investment Commission. At an average approximate cost of $24 per search for in excess of 480 providers, this would cost in excess of $11,600 in addition to staff time.

DETYA has not taken this further step because the ESOS Act does not preclude the "owners", "operators" or "managers" from also being registered migration agents. In fact, the (voluntary) Ministerial Council on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs (MCEETYA) Code of Practice in the Provision of International Education and Training Services places an obligation on providers to inform students of the Migration Act and regulations governing their students' entry to and stay in Australia.

Further, under provisions of the Migration Act 1958 and the Migration Agents Regulations 1998, anyone who uses knowledge of migration procedures to offer assistance to a person wishing to obtain a visa to enter or remain in Australia must register as an agent with the Migration Agents Registration Authority.

(2) The Department does not routinely monitor magazine advertisements. When DETYA receives information about advertisements which may involve a provider engaging in misleading or deceptive conduct in connection with the recruitment of intending overseas students, DETYA investigates any issues which may involve breaches of the ESOS Act.

(3) Under section 12 of the ESOS Act, if a provider engages in misleading or deceptive conduct in connection with the recruitment of intending overseas students, the provider's registration may be cancelled from CRICOS.

In the past, DETYA has investigated cases reported as possibly involving misleading and deceptive behaviour. In all instances, the matters were satisfactorily explained and did not justify cancellation of the providers' registration from CRICOS. DETYA has no current investigations of this type.
(4) The Department does not monitor actual enrolment or attendance.
There is no legislative requirement for DETYA to monitor student attendance, nor is there any requirement under the ESOS Act for providers to report non-attendance.

The Migration Act 1958 requires students to be enrolled on a full time basis in a course registered on CRICOS before they can be issued with a student visa. When they have entered Australia to study, student visa conditions stipulate, inter alia, that students must satisfy course requirements and maintain a valid enrolment. In order to satisfy course requirements, students must:
. be enrolled in a registered course; and
. have at least 80% attendance rate (according to records of the education provider), or
. if evidence of attendance cannot be provided, achieve satisfactory academic performance as . . certified by the education provider; and
. pay tuition fees as required by the provider.
Failure to satisfy course requirements will result in cancellation of the student's visa.

There is no legislative requirement for providers to advise DIMA of student non-attendance. Under the (voluntary) MCEETYA Code of Practice in the Provision of International Education and Training Services, providers are required to notify the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs if a student is no longer participating in the course for which they were enrolled.

DETYA advises providers of their obligations under the MCEETYA Code of Practice when they become registered on CRICOS. The Code is also included in the DETYA publication "A Guide for Providers of Education and Training Services to Overseas Students" which is issued to all providers registered on CRICOS.
(5) There is no legislative requirement for DETYA to monitor or ensure conformity with maximum enrolment entitlements, or to monitor the transfer of students from one provider to another.
The State and Territory authorities determine maximum enrolment capacity as part of the registration process.
(6) The Department does not track and monitor attendance of students who transfer between institutions in Australia. There is no legislative requirement for DETYA to do so.

Under conditions attached to their visa for entry into Australia to study, students must study with the education provider where they initially enrolled for the first year of the course, or for the duration of the course if the it is less than one year. Students may apply to DIMA to change providers during their first year only in exceptional circumstances. After the first year of study there is no legislative requirement for students to notify DIMA if they transfer from one provider to another.
Student visa conditions further stipulate that students must satisfy course requirements. In order to satisfy course requirements, students must:
. be enrolled in a registered course; and
. have at least 80% attendance rate (according to records of the education provider), or
. if evidence of attendance cannot be provided, achieve satisfactory academic performance as certified by the education provider; and
. pay tuition fees as required by the provider.
Failure to satisfy course requirements will result in cancellation of the student's visa.

Under the (voluntary) MCEETYA Code of Practice in the Provision of International Education and Training Services providers should to notify DIMA if a student is no longer participating in the course for which they were enrolled.
There is no legislative requirement for providers to advise DIMA of student non-attendance.

(7) DETYA does not hold this information. There is no legislative requirement for DETYA to monitor providers to determine if their student enrolments exceed the approved enrolment capacity registered on CRICOS.

The State and Territory authorities approve the registration of institutions for a maximum capacity of enrolments. Any monitoring of compliance would be the responsibility of those authorities. No State or Territory authority has advised DETYA that any provider has exceeded their maximum enrolment capacity.
(8) (a) Twelve. (1 x FAS (partial), 1 x AS (partial), 1 x SOG B, 2 x SOG C, 4 x ASO 6, 2 x ASO 5, 1 x ASO 3)
(b) Twelve. (1 x FAS(partial), 1 x AS (partial), 1 x SOG B, 3 x SOG C, 2 x ASO 6, 2 x ASO 5, 2 x ASO 3)
(c) FAS: Exercise delegated powers, oversight Branch
AS: Exercise delegated powers, oversight Section
SOG B: management and co-ordination of the Section's activities
SOG C x 2: review of the ESOS Act, Parliamentary matters, some administration of the ESOS Act
SOG C x 1: Parliamentary matters (briefs, questions etc), some administration of the ESOS Act
ASO 6 x 1: administration of the ESOS Act, including monitoring provider compliance with the reporting, financial and tuition guarantee requirements
ASO 6 x 1: IT systems development, including electronic Confirmation of Enrolment system
ASO 5 x 2: administration of the ESOS Act, including monitoring provider compliance with the reporting, financial and tuition guarantee requirements
ASO 3 x 1: systems support, including electronic Confirmation of Enrolment form
ASO 3 x 1: CRICOS management
(d) Three + 1 x ASO 6 and 2 x ASO 5, with some assistance from the IT ASO 6 and 3 x SOG C.

(9) DETYA does not have the responsibility to monitor the business affairs of private education providers nor does the ESOS Act empower DETYA to enquire into a provider's financial dealings other than in respect of its notified trust account.

DETYA is responsible for administering the ESOS Act, the primary objectives of which are to safeguard students' money and to ensure that students receive the education and training for which they have paid.
Since the tuition guarantee provisions of the Act were introduced in 1994, the registration of 11 providers has been cancelled from CRICOS as a result of financial failure.

The percentage of providers whose registration has been cancelled from CRICOS as a result of financial failure has varied from year to year. Table 1 at Attachment A summarises overall cancellations and cancellations resulting from financial failure.

In eight of the cases of financial failure, displaced students have either received the education and training for which they had paid, been refunded their tuition fees or received an appropriate insurance payment. In two cases there were no students enrolled. The remaining case, National Colleges of Australia Pty Ltd has not yet been concluded, but the insurance company has made payment to its legal representative and individual payments to eligible students will be made in November.

(10) (a) DETYA has conducted enquiries into the conduct of three providers for apparently engaging in misleading and deceptive conduct in connection with the recruitment of intending overseas students in the past 12 months.

These enquiries related to inadequate premises, teaching and equipment. In all cases, the providers were holding themselves out as being able to provide education and training services to overseas students when DETYA had received information suggesting that their premises, teaching and equipment were inadequate, sub-standard or non-existent.

DETYA raised these matters with each provider directly under subsection 12(1)(a) of the ESOS Act and concurrently referred them to NSW Vocational Education and Training Accreditation Board for appropriate action.
As a result of the Department's enquiries and the written submissions received, cancellation action was not considered justified.

On the basis of an anonymous complaint, a preliminary enquiry was made into another provider's activities but was not progressed as it did not reveal that the provider had engaged in activity contravening the ESOS Act.
(b) In the past 12 months, DETYA has conducted eight enquiries into institutions recruiting students into courses not registered on CRICOS.

Subsection 4(1) of the ESOS Act requires that for an institution or other body or person to recruit, enrol and teach overseas students, the institution or other body or person must be registered on CRICOS in respect of the course which is proposed to be provided.

In the first stage of enquiries of this type, DETYA writes to the institution concerned, outlining the apparent case against it and providing advice on the institution's legal obligations in providing education and training services to overseas students. The institution is given an opportunity to make submissions in respect of the allegations against it. At the same time the relevant State or Territory education authority responsible for approving the registration of institutions to enrol overseas students is notified.

Depending on the nature and extent of the institution's submission, the case is either brought to a satisfactory conclusion with no further action taken or is progressed to the next stage. If the institution's submission is unsatisfactory, the case is referred to DETYA's Legal and Fraud Branch for further consideration.

To date, five of the eight enquiries conducted in the past 12 months have been satisfactorily resolved with no further action being taken. Two of the remaining three cases have been referred to Legal and Fraud Branch to determine if further investigation is warranted. The remaining case is being investigated by the National Investigations Unit of the Legal and Fraud Branch with a view to progressing the case to the Director of Public Prosecutions for action under subsection 4(1A) of the ESOS Act.
(c) There is no legislative requirement for providers to notify DETYA of student non-attendance therefore, DETYA has not conducted investigations of this type.
(11) (a) None.

(b) Two. Both complaints came from parents whose children were enrolled in colleges which failed earlier this year + Business Institute of Victoria Pty Ltd (BIV) and National Colleges of Australia Pty Ltd (NCA). The complaints were both expressed in terms of the students not receiving a refund of their pre-paid course money or being provided with appropriate alternative tuition. The student enrolled at BIV is receiving appropriate alternative tuition and DETYA has been advised that NCA's insurance company has made payment to its legal representative and individual payments to eligible students will be made in November.
(c) Fourteen.

Eight students contacted DETYA complaining that they had not been paid a refund of their pre-paid course money when, for a variety of reasons, they had withdrawn from their course. Each of the students was enrolled with a different provider. DETYA investigated each complaint and as a result, three of the students have been paid appropriate refunds by providers. In four cases it was determined that the students were not entitled to a refund either under the terms and conditions of the providers' refund policy or under the provisions of the ESOS Act. The remaining complaint is still being investigated.

Four students contacted DETYA complaining about the quality of the education and training they had received. Two of these students were enrolled with private education providers and two were enrolled at TAFE institutes. In all cases, the complaints were referred to the relevant State education authority for resolution.
Two other students contacted DETYA with general complaints about their providers. These were referred to the relevant State education authority for resolution.

(d) There have been allegations made by industry representative bodies about the operations of providers not complying with the provisions of the ESOS Act. Similarly, they have complained of providers acting in an unethical manner or not in the best interests of the industry. When such matters are raised, DETYA encourages people to provide documentary evidence or a signed statement in order that there is evidence on which to base an investigation.
No industry representative body has provided documentary evidence or been prepared to submit a statement attesting to claims made.
(e) Five.
During 1999, three providers made a series of complaints, allegations and counter allegations about the operations, quality of facilities and advertising of each other.

None of the allegations could be substantiated and no action was taken except in relation to an allegation that one provider was advertising and inviting intending overseas students to enrol in its courses before it was registered on CRICOS.

As a result of its investigation, DETYA concluded that the provider had contravened subsection 4(1) of the ESOS Act during July and August by advertising its courses on the Internet and at a trade fair. However, action was not considered justified as it was not an intentional or reckless contravention of the ESOS Act.
In June 1999, a provider alleged that a number of overseas students were undertaking practical flight training with flying schools in Western Australia which were not registered on CRICOS.

DETYA's investigation of the complaint revealed that no breach of the ESOS Act had occurred as the students in question were enrolled with a CRICOS provider and the education and training was being provided by that provider.
DETYA's investigation did not reveal any breach of Commonwealth or State legislation.

In October 1998, a provider wrote to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs concerning possible abuses of student visas and misleading advertising by education providers in respect of overseas students. DIMA referred the matter to DETYA.

DETYA's investigation (including having materials translated) revealed that no provider registered on CRICOS was involved, but that a number of Sydney based migration agents were involved. The agents had placed advertisements in a local Japanese language publication, suggesting they could provide assistance in obtaining visa extensions and resolving visa problems.
There is no legislative basis for DETYA to take action against migration agents and the matter was referred back to DIMA for their attention and appropriate action.

(12) (a) The list supplied in answer to part (4) of question on notice no 1361 was required to provide information on the number overseas students enrolled with providers registered on CRICOS on 30 June 1998 and 30 June 1999. Caprock International Pty Ltd, trading as Lloyds International College, CRICOS provider number 01942A, was not registered on CRICOS until 2 July 1999.
(b) Yes.
In addition to Caprock International Pty Ltd, another 25 non-exempt providers have been registered on CRICOS since 30 June 1999.
