talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 22 October 1999:

question.para: With reference to the trial of an air-ground operator at Ayers Rock airport:
(1) (a) When did the trial begin; and (b) when will the trial end.
(2) Was the trial successful; if so, why is it being terminated; if not, why not.
(3) Was there a serious incident relating to a Qantas aircraft during the trial; if so: (a) what are the details; (b) what action has been taken; and (c) when.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) and the Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB) have provided the following information:
(1) (a) The trial commenced at 10.00 am on Tuesday, 14 September 1999.
(b) The trial ended at 3.00pm on Monday, 25 October 1999.
(2) The trial was a success. The safety benefits of the Certified Air/Ground Radio service which the trial provided are presently being assessed by CASA.

The trial was terminated as the contract for its provision between the Ayers Rock Resort (Yulara) and the private sector service provider expired at the end of the planned six weeks period of the trial.

The purpose of the trial, which was to provide the information necessary to enable CASA to assess the level of safety enhancement afforded, and to evaluate the operational procedures employed, was satisfied.
(3) An incident on 27 September 1999, involving a Qantas aircraft at Yulara, was reported to the ATSB.

(a) The ATSB has advised that the air/ground radio service operator at Yulara reported that the aircraft taxied and departed without the crew making the appropriate MBZ radio transmissions. No other aircraft were operating in the area at the time. The crew had selected one of their two radios to the flight service radio frequency with the other selected to the airline company frequency.

The investigation determined that prior to making the taxi broadcast, the crew did not confirm that the selected radio was tuned to the MBZ frequency. Consequently the crew inadvertently transmitted their taxi and departure broadcasts on the airline company radio frequency.
The air/ground radio operator confirmed that he had heard the crew of the aircraft make the separate required broadcast on the flight service frequency which he monitored.

(b) The airline operator requested that the air/ground radio operator contact flight service during future non-compliance events, with a request that the flight service officer attempt to contact the aircrew to establish communications and direct crews to the MBZ frequency.
CASA advised the ATSB that it will review such coordination aspects during the assessment of the trial.
(c) Refer to (b) above.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 28 October 1999:

question.para: (1) On how many occasions has Mr Stephen Skehill been engaged as a consultant, or in any other capacity, or engaged on a retainer, by the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) or the CASA Board.
(2) On each occasion: (a) what was the purpose of the consultancy; (b) what was the cost of the consultancy; and (c) what was the duration of the consultancy.
(3) If Mr Skehill was engaged on a retainer, what were the details of that engagement.

(4) Was each consultancy, or other form of engagement, undertaken by Mr Skehill the subject of a tender process; if so, on each occasion: (a) how many tenders were received; and (b) who lodged those tenders; if not, why not.

(5) Has Mr Skehill provided seminars, or some other form of briefing, on the requirements of corporate governance to CASA staff; if so: (a) to what areas of the authority were the seminars or briefings provided; (b) what was the date of each seminar or briefing; (c) who attended each seminar or briefing; (d) what was the cost of each seminar or briefing; and (e) for each seminar or briefing, who invited Mr Skehill to undertake that work.
(6) (a) Can a breakdown be provided of costs associated with each of the above seminars or briefings; and (b) in each instance, who formally approved funding for these seminars or briefings.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

answer.para: The Civil Aviation Safety Authority has provided the following information:

(1) Mr Stephen Skehill has never been directly engaged or remunerated by the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) or the CASA Board. Mr Skehill is employed as Special Counsel by the firm Mallesons Stephen Jaques. That firm has been appointed to the CASA legal panel. On occasions, legal work assigned by CASA to Mallesons Stephen Jaques has been undertaken by Mr Skehill on behalf of Mallesons Stephen Jaques. Mallesons Stephen Jaques is remunerated on negotiated hourly or other rates and has no retainer from CASA.
(2) See (1) above
(3) Not applicable

(4) The appointment of Mallesons Stephen Jaques to the CASA legal panel was as a result of a competitive tender process conducted by CASA in January 1998. The panel was established on 1 June 1998. The other firm selected for the panel is Phillips Fox. On each occasion that external legal work is assigned by CASA, consideration is given to which of the panel firms is best able to meet CASA's needs.
(a) CASA invited 10 private national law firms and the Australian Government Solicitor to submit tenders. Eight tenders were received by CASA.
(b) The successful tenderers were Phillips Fox and Mallesons Stephen Jaques
. For reasons of commercial confidentiality CASA considers it inappropriate to name unsuccessful tenderers but notes that these included a significant number of highly respected legal firms.
(5) Mr Skehill has provided two briefing sessions on corporate governance issues for CASA staff.

(a)—(c) The first, held on 17 June 1999, was attended by the CASA Executive Management Team. The second, held on 28 June 1999, was attended by senior officers of CASA's Aviation Safety Compliance Division.
(d) The cost of each seminar was 17 June 1999—$1,428 and 28 June 1999—$1,008.
(e) Mr Skehill was invited to conduct each of these sessions by, or with the approval of, the Director of Aviation Safety.
(6) (a) The breakdown of the cost of each seminar is as follows:
(i) 17 June 1999—this seminar was for Canberra-based staff and thus the only direct cost was the fee paid to Mallesons Stephen Jaques: $1,428.
(ii) 28 June 1999—this seminar was for staff who were otherwise present in Canberra on official duty and thus the only direct cost was the fee paid to Mallesons Stephen Jaques: $1,008.
(b) The cost of these sessions was funded by the Office of Legal Counsel.
